page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Libyan Civil War and military intervention (19 March–May)

revision.text:
{{main|2011 Libyan civil war}} :''The events regarding the military intervention on 19 March can be tracked in the related articles:'' :''[[Timeline of the 2011 Libyan Civil War before military intervention]]'' :''[[Timeline of the 2011 Libyan Civil War and military intervention (June–15 August)]]'' :''[[Timeline of the 2011 Libyan Civil War and military intervention (16 August – 23 October)]]''
{{Infobox |title =Map of Libya |image =[[File:Libyan war final.svg|300px]] |alt = |caption =<div style="text-align:left">Progress of the Libya civil war. {{legend|#d45500|Held by anti-Gaddafi factions by 1 March. (Checkered: Lost before International intervention on 19 March.)}} {{legend|#d4aa00|Contested areas between March and August.}} {{legend|#d38d5f|Rebel western coastal offensive in August.}} {{legend|#ffb380|Rebel gains by 1 October.}} {{legend|#afe9af|Last loyalist pockets.}} [[File:Big battle symbol.svg|30px]] Major campaigns. [[File:Small battle symbol.svg|20px]] battles. }}
The [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]] began on 15 February 2011 as a civil protest and later evolved into a widespread uprising. However, by 19 March, Libyan forces under Colonel [[Muammar Gaddafi]] were on the brink of a decisive victory over rebels in [[Cyrenaica|Libya's east]]. That day, leading [[NATO]] members acted on [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973]] which authorized member states "to take all necessary measures... to protect civilians and civilian populated areas under threat of attack in the [[Libyan Arab Jamahiriya]], including [[Benghazi]], while excluding an occupation force".<ref name="UN News Centre">{{cite web | url= http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=37808 |title=Security Council Authorizes 'All Necessary Measures' To Protect Civilians in Libya|date=17 March 2011|publisher=UN News Centre|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
Following the implementation of a [[2011 military intervention in Libya|Libyan no-fly zone]], the [[Battle of Ajdabiya]] and the [[Second Battle of Benghazi]], the rebels recovered all territory lost in the Gaddafi loyalist offensive. However, due to the bulk of their forces being armed civilians lacking both leadership and communication, they quickly fell into disarray and were forced into retreat.<ref>{{Cite news| author = Calder, Ryan | date=4 April 2011|work=The Berkeley Blog (blog of the [[University of California, Berkeley]]) | url= http://blogs.berkeley.edu/2011/04/04/accordion-war-why-does-the-front-in-libya-keep-moving-back-and-forth/| title = Accordion War: Why Does the Front in Libya Keep Moving Back and Forth?|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
With NATO attacks increasing in both severity and frequency, numerous defections amongst Gaddafi's military and political elite, and steadily increasing support from the international community, the opposition was able to make limited gains towards the end of May. After being [[Battle of Misrata|besieged since February]], opposition forces pushed loyalist forces out of Misrata and into its outskirts, beginning a [[Battle of the Misrata frontline|battle]] for control of [[Misrata District|the area]].
[[File:Sirt Front-final.svg|thumb|right|300px|alt=|Overview map of [[Fourth Battle of Brega|developments at the Gulf of Sidra]]. Dates for changes of hand of individual towns are given in red (rebel offensive) and green (government offensive).]] [[File:Tripolitanian Front-final.svg|thumb|right|300px|alt=|Overview map of [[2011 Libyan rebel coastal offensive|developments in Tripolitania]]. Dates for changes of hand of individual towns are given in red (rebel offensive) and green (government offensive).]] [[File:Battle of Misrata.svg|thumb|right|300px|alt=|Overview map of [[Battle of Misrata|developments in Misrata]].]]
{{TOC limit|2}} {{Campaignbox Libyan civil war}} {{Campaignbox Military intervention in Libya}}
==Start of coalition intervention (19–25 March)==
===19 March=== {{main|Second Battle of Benghazi}} *By unanimous vote, Denmark's [[Folketing|Parliament]] authorized direct military action by its air force to help enforce [[UN Security Council Resolution 1973]], marking the only time so far in the state's history that military commitment was supported by full parliamentary unity.<ref>{{cite news|date=19 March 2011|url=http://borsen.dk/nyheder/weekend_og_nat/natteside/artikel/ritzau/3/CHR-291317.html|title=''Enigt Folketing stemmer for krig i Libyen''|language=Danish|work=[[Dagbladet Børsen]]|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> Despite the Libyan government's assertion that they were respecting the UN-mandated ceasefire, pro-Gaddafi forces entered the suburbs of Benghazi, and were shelling the city with mortars and artillery.<ref name="Jazeera 2011-3-19">{{cite news|work=[[Al Jazeera]] |title=Libya Live Blog – 19 March |date=18 March 2011 |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-19 |accessdate=30 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xJ4lwmv0 |archivedate=19 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Golovnina|first1=Maria|last2=Georgy|first2=Michael|agency=Reuters|date=19 March 2011|title=Western Warplanes, Missiles Hit Libyan Targets|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/19/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110319|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> *Pro-Gaddafi forces were reported in the suburbs of Benghazi and shelling the city with artillery from {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} away.<ref name="Jazeera 2011-3-19"/> Pro-Gaddafi tanks inside Benghazi were reported by a [[BBC News]] journalist. *Also on 19 March, a [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-23|MiG-23BN]] was shot down over Benghazi by ground fire. A rebel spokesman later confirmed that the plane belonged to the [[Free Libyan Air Force]] and had been engaged in error by rebels.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12496420|work=BBC News |title=Libyan Private and State Media Slant Protest Coverage|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="rayment/telegraph19march">Rayment, Sean (19 March 2011). [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8393237/Libya-moment-a-rebel-jet-crashed-to-earth-in-flames.html "Libya: Moment a Rebel Jet Crashed to Earth in Flames]. ''The Daily Telegraph''. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref><ref name="rayment/telegraph19march"/><ref name="AJ19march112208"> Staff (19 March 2011). [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/03/201131934914112208.html "Gaddafi Forces Encroaching on Benghazi]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref><ref name="AJ19march112208"/><ref name="xinhuanet1"/><ref name="myfoxlubbock-planeshotdown"> {{cite web|url=http://www.myfoxlubbock.com/news/world/story/Plane-shot-down-over-rebel-held-city-in-Libya/9x2_eMAtKU6TqK6LILL-rw.cspx|title=Plane Shot Down over Rebel-Held City in Libya|publisher=Associated Press (via [[KJTV-TV]])|date=19 March 2011|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> [[Fox News]] initially reported that the plane was "bombing their (rebels) eastern stronghold".<ref name="myfoxlubbock-planeshotdown"/>
*The Libyan government said the rebels violated the UN "no fly" resolution by using a helicopter and a fighter jet to bomb Libyan armed forces.<ref name="xinhuanet1">{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-03/19/c_13787579.htm|title=Fighter Plane Shot Down in Libya's Benghazi: Al-Jazeera|publisher=Xinhua News Agency|date=19 March 2011|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> *Libyan state television said that [[Minister of the Interior (Libyan)|Libyan Interior Minister]] [[Abdul Fatah Younis]], who had defected to the opposition one month ago, had returned to the government.<ref name=rec1>{{cite news|publisher=BBC News |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12931731|title=Libya Air Raid 'Killed Civilians'|accessdate=31 March 2011|date=1 April 2011}}</ref> The head of the [[Libyan National Council]], [[Mustafa Abdul Jalil]], denied this report.<ref name="Jazeera 2011-3-19"/> On a live phone call with Al Jazeera, Younis confirmed that he was still in Benghazi and on the rebels' side, and that videos of him on state television were from a meeting with Gaddafi months ago. *At 4 pm (Libyan time), French [[Dassault Rafale|fighter jets]] began entering Libyan airspace in reconnaissance missions in support of the [[Libyan no-fly zone]].<ref name="Jazeera 2011-3-19"/> *[[Mohammed Nabbous]], founder of [[Libya Alhurra TV]], died in the [[Second Battle of Benghazi]].<ref name="Jazeera 2011-3-19"/> *At 6:45 pm local time, a French fighter jet fired the first shots, hitting government military armored vehicles.<ref>Staff (20 March 2011). [http://www.statesman.com/news/nation/france-fires-on-libyan-military-vehicle-1331885.html?page=2 "World Intervenes in Libya, with Unusual Speed"]. Associated Press (via ''[[Austin American-Statesman]]''). Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref> Al Jazeera reported the next day that the air raid had destroyed a convoy of fourteen tanks and several trucks loaded with RPGs and ammunition, fourteen pro-Gaddafi soldiers were reported dead after the raid.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} *According to Al Jazeera, some citizens of Benghazi were leaving the city and moving northwest to other anti-Gaddafi held towns. Later reports from Al Jazeera/Pentagon relations told that American warships had launched cruise missiles at Libyan airfields as part of a multi-phase operation called [[Odyssey Dawn]]. After that, the US planned to focus on the skirmishes on the ground. The Pentagon said that the United Arab Emirates and Qatar would also be involved in military operations in Libya, but would announce their involvement themselves.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} *[[Operation Odyssey Dawn]], falls under the operational command of the [[US African Command|AFRICOM]], under General [[Carter Ham]]. Tactical execution was being run out of the [[USS Mount Whitney (LCC-20)|USS ''Mount Whitney'']], Admiral [[Samuel J. Locklear|Sam Locklear]] commanding. Off the coast of Libya, there were: 11 vessels from Italy, 11 from the US (including three submarines, each with 112 missiles on board), one from the UK, one from France and one from Canada.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} *Later that day, Gaddafi's Secretary General of the People's Congress, [[Mohammad al-Zawi]], had a press conference in which he repeatedly claimed that the ceasefire was in action, contradictory to reports from Al Jazeera, BBC News and other Western news sources. Libyan state television later claimed that Gaddafi forces had shot down a French military plane. *The [[African Union]] ''Ad Hoc'' High-Level Committee on Libya met.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/african-union-ad-hoc-high-level-committee-libya-meets-nouakchott-19-march-2011 |title=The African Union Ad Hoc High-Level Committee on Libya Meets In Nouakchott on 19 March 2011. | African Union |publisher=Au.int |date= |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref>
===20 March=== {{See also|Battle of Misrata}} *At about 2:30 am local time, anti-aircraft gunfire was heard for about seven minutes echoing throughout [[Tripoli]]; it was unknown what targets were hit.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} Later, Libya state television reported that airstrikes killed 48 people and wounded 150 in civilian areas.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Citing an armed-forces statement, it said Tripoli as well as Benghazi, Misrata and Zuwarah were also hit.<!--ref name="Live Blog Libya"/--> *Libyan armed men on the port of Tripoli captured an Italian ship with eleven crew members – eight from Italy, two from India and one from Ukraine.<ref name="Sanskar Shrivastava">{{cite news|author=Shrivastava, Sanskar|date=20 March 2011|url=http://www.theworldreporter.com/2011/03/italian-ship-captured-in-libya-gaddafi.html|work=The World Reporter|title=Italian Ship Captured in Libya, Gaddafi Called West Barbarians; Full Speech|accessdate=2 April 2011}}</ref> The ship, the ''[[ASSO 22]]'' – belonging to the [[Augusta Off Shore Society]] – was sending staff of [[Eni]], an Italian multinational oil-and-gas company,<ref name="Sanskar Shrivastava"/> to Libya. It had arrived in Tripoli in the afternoon of 19 March; after the staff departed, the crew was held up by the armed personnel of the port. *Al Jazeera reported that on 20 March an air strike had destroyed fourteen tanks, twenty armored-troop carriers and several trucks filled with ammunition and [[rocket-propelled grenade]]s, killing fourteen pro-Gaddafi soldiers in the process.<ref>{{cite web|author=Fisher, Alan|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rb-X14nH9kw|title=Gaddafi Condemns Attack on His Forces|publisher=Al Jazeera|format=video (00:02:38)|date=20 March 2011|accessdate=2 April 2011}}</ref> Three of Gaddafi's tanks had just reached the centre of rebel-held [[Misrata]], a spokesman for the armed opposition told Al Jazeera.<ref name="AJblog19-20march">Staff (19 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-20-0 "Libya Live Blog – 20 March]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 2 April 2011.</ref> The same source reported that pro-Gaddhafi boats did not allow help to reach Misrata. Casualties were reported to be too high to count.<ref name="AJblog19-20march"/> *The [[Government of the People's Republic of China|People's Republic of China]], the [[government of Russia|Russia]] and the [[Arab League]] condemned the violence from the US and France with Russia claiming that the [[UN Security Council]] resolution had been "hastily adopted".{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} At about 5:10 pm local time, a health official in Tripoli increased the death toll from forty-eight to sixty-four.{{when|date=April 2011}} More anti-aircraft fire was heard in Tripoli at about 8:30 am local time. At 9:00 pm local time the government once again called for a ceasefire.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} However, Al Jazeera reporters later questioned the spokesperson for the military, he replied that no one would in the public would be informed of this by media. At 10:26 pm local time a loud explosion was reported nearby Gaddafi's compound, [[Bab al-Azizia]] in Tripoli.<ref name="AJblog19-20march"/> It was confirmed by CNN <!--by Nick Robertson, who, once appropriate citation is found, doesn't need to be name in prose--> that a building at the heart of the Azizia compound had been destroyed.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
===21 March=== {{See also|2011 Nafusa Mountains Campaign|Battle of Ajdabiya#Second phase}} *It was reported by [[Al Manara Media]], that [[Khamis Gaddafi]], the leader of the [[Khamis Brigade]] and Gaddafi's son, had died from his injuries sustained when Muhammad Mokhtar Osman allegedly crashed his plane into [[Bab al-Azizia]] a week earlier. However, this was not confirmed by any other independent media. The crashing of the plane had also not been previously reported or confirmed by any other independent media except Al Manara. *[[Swiss people|Swiss]] journalist [[Gaëtan Vannay]], reporting from [[Zintan]] in [[Tripolitania]], said the eastern environs of Zintan had seen fighting between rebels and attacking government forces for the past two days. There was heavy shelling on the city by pro-Gaddafi forces.<ref>Staff (20 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-21-0 "Libya Live Blog – 21 March"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref> *Following a meeting with [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|UN Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki Moon]], Arab League Secretary-General [[Amr Moussa]] stated his support for the no-fly zone being implemented over Libya.<ref>Eleiba, Ahmed (21 March 2011). [http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/8259/World/Region/Arab-Leagues-Amr-Moussa-defends-its-support-for-UN.aspx "Arab League's Amr Moussa Defends Its Support for UN no-fly Zone Resolution"]. ''[[Al-Ahram]]''. Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref> *The BBC News reported that the [[Libyan Permanent Mission to United Nations]] was now flying the former [[Flag of Libya|Libyan flag]] and an image of this flag appeared on the mission's official website which had also removed an image of Gaddafi from its index page.<ref>[http://www.libyanmission-un.org/ Libyan Mission New York]. Libyanmission-un.org (5 March 2011). Retrieved 1 May 2011.</ref> *There were four pro-Gaddafi tanks on the road outside [[Ajdabiya]], which fired on any vehicle that goes over a rise approaching the city.<ref>Clark, Mandy. ''[[CBS Evening News]]''. 21 March 2011.</ref> *[[Prime Minister of Russia|Russian Prime Minister]] [[Vladimir Putin]], stated that the execution of the no-fly zone was comparable to the medieval crusades.<ref>Staff (21 March 2011). [http://www.9and10news.com/Category/Story/?id=285492&cID=3 "No New Air Strikes...Reporters Released...Putin Criticizes Libya Strikes"]. Associated Press (via [[WWTV]]). Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref> [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] described Putin's comments as "unacceptable".<ref>Staff (22 March 2011). [http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/125670/20110322/libya-russia.htm "Putin Downplays Alleged Tiff with Medvedev over Libya"]. ''[[International Business Times]]''. Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref>
===22 March=== *Late 21 March, [[Al Arabiya]] quoted a Libyan government official who said administration of Misrata was re-taken by pro-Gaddafi government, however rebels claimed that they still controlled the city.<ref name="AJblog21-22march">Staff (21 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/live-blog-libya-march-22 "Live Blog Libya – 22 March"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> A caller from Misrata to CNN's ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' reported that there was still resistance. *''[[Haaretz]]'' reported that the Commander of the International Coalition for Libya stated that civilians were being targeted by pro-Gaddafi forces in Misrata.<ref name="Haaretz.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/u-s-libya-forces-attack-civilians-in-third-largest-city-of-misrata-1.351159|work=[[Haaretz]]|title=U.S.: Libya Forces Attack Civilians in Third Largest City of Misrata|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> A Misratan resident told ''The World Today'' that pro-Gaddafi forces in Misrata had been ordering people to march to the city square and demonstrate their support for Gaddafi's government and that when an anti-Gaddafi demonstration broke out, the pro-Gaddafi forces fired into the crowd of 4,000 using heavy artillery and snipers, killing twenty-seven people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/22/3170602.htm?section=justin|title=27 Killed in Ceasefire Breach, Libyan Says|accessdate=10 April 2011|date=22 March 2011|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]}}</ref> *According to the results of a [[ComRes]]/[[ITN]] poll released on 21 March, one in three Britons agreed with the decision to take military action in Libya. The survey found that 43% disagreed with the action and 22% were unsure. However, a separate survey by [[YouGov]] showed the opposite result with a majority of Britons questioned supporting the campaign.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Anderson, Katie |author2=Thompson, Hannah |url=http://today.yougov.co.uk/politics/libya-british-support-sanctions|title=Libya: British Supports Sanctions|publisher=[[YouGov]]|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/the-staggers/2011/03/british-public-support-action|title=The Staggers: Libya Polls Show That British Public Is Divided|author=Shackle, Samira|work=New Statesman|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> *According to a ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' reporter embedded with the rebels, coalition forces began bombing Gaddafi forces around Adjabiya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/mar/22/libya-no-fly-zone-air-strikes-live-updates|work=The Guardian |location=UK|author1=Gabbatt, Adam |author2=Tran, Mark |author3=Haynes, Jonathan |title=Libya Air Strikes – Tuesday 22 March Part 1|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> *A [[United States Air Force|USAF]] [[F-15E]] warplane crashed in Libya;<ref name="Haaretz.com"/><ref>{{cite news|author1=Crilly, Rob |author2=Kirkup, James |author3=Winnett, Rob |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8397587/Libya-US-fighter-jet-crash-lands-in-field-near-Benghazi.html|title=Libya: US Fighter Jet Crash Lands in Field Near Benghazi|accessdate=10 April 2011|date=22 March 2011|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK}}</ref> its pilots had minor injuries. One of the pilots was recovered a US [[V-22 Osprey]]; the other was found by anti-Gaddafi forces and given shelter. The crash was blamed on mechanical failure.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12816226|title=Libya Crisis: US Warplane Crew Rescued after Crash|work=BBC News|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> *In response to Russia's call for an immediate cease fire,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2011/03/22/russia-calls-for-immediate-cease-fire-in-libya/|title=Russia Calls for Immediate Cease-Fire in Libya|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=22 March 2011}}</ref> US Defense Secretary [[Robert Gates]] said, "some Russians were swallowing Muammar Gaddafi's lies about civilian casualties in Libya"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE72L0EK20110322|title=Update 4 – Libya Clouds U.S. Defense Chief's Russia Visit|agency= [[Reuters]]|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> and said the coalition forces were doing their best to avoid civilian casualties. *Hussein el Warfali, commander of the pro-Gaddafi Eagle Brigade in Tripoli, was reported killed.<ref name="AJblog21-22march"/> *Plans by coalition forces to hit Gaddafi's compound with [[Storm Shadow]] cruise missiles were aborted after journalists were taken there to show them the damage from the original attack.<ref name="AJblog21-22march"/> *Following an interview with US Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] by [[ABC News]], it was reported that "People close to Muammar Gaddafi are reaching out to allies around the world exploring their options". Clinton also stated that she was aware of reports that one of Gaddafi's sons had been killed in non-coalition air strikes but that the "evidence is not sufficient" for her to confirm this.<ref>Khan, Huma (22 March 2011). [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/hillary-clinton-diane-sawyer-moammar-gadhafi-allies-seeking/story?id=13196414 "Exclusive: Gadhafi, Allies May Be Seeking Way Out, Clinton Tells ABC News in World News Interview, Secretary of State Downplays Concerns about Coalition and Power Transfer: 'I'm Very Relaxed'"]. [[ABC News]]. Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref>
===23 March=== *Gaddafi's forces launched a heavy bombardment on Zintan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/19/libya-zintan-tanks-idUSWEA958320110319|title=Gaddafi Attacks Libya's Zintan – Al Arabiya|agency=[[Reuters]] |date=19 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> *Loyalist forces in Misrata captured the main hospital and positioned snipers on its roof. The opposition requested a hospital ship be sent to Misrata.<ref name="AJblog22-23march">Staff (22 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-23 "Libya Live Blog – 23 March]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 31 March 2011.</ref> *Coalition forces launched air strikes on Gaddafi's forces within the city of Misrata itself. Coalition jets also launched air strikes against Gaddafi forces at Ajdabiya's eastern gate.<ref name="AJblog22-23march"/> People fleeing the city stated that only the center of the city remained in rebel hands while the outskirts were under government control.<ref>Staff (23 March 2011). [http://www.bostonherald.com/news/international/africa/view/20110323libyan_forces_pull_back_from_western_city/srvc=news&position=recent_bullet "Strikes Force Gadhafi Back; NATO Ships Patrol Sea"]. [[Associated Press]] (via ''[[Boston Herald]]''). Retrieved 31 March 2011.</ref> *A British military officer claimed that Libya's air force "no longer exists as a fighting force" due to coalition air strikes and that coalition aircraft are now "operating with impunity" over Libya.<ref name="Al Jazeera">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/03/201132316258646677.html|title=Libyan Air Force 'No Longer Exists'|work=Al Jazeera |date=23 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> [[Air Vice Marshal]] [[Greg Bagwell]] stated: "We've blown up all their airplanes."<ref>{{cite news|author1=Wheeler, Virginia |author2=Willetts, David |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/3486913/Top-Guns-destroy-Gaddafi-air-force.html?OTC-RSS&ATTR=News|title=Top Guns Destroy Gaddafi Air Force|work=The Sun |location=UK |date=23 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> *Libya's pro-democracy fighters formed an "interim government", headed by [[Mahmoud Jibril]].<ref name="Al Jazeera"/> *Eight explosions from coalition bombings were heard after sunset in eastern Tripoli. <ref name="AJblog22-23march"/>
*The Bab Al-Azizia compound was also bombed again.<ref>Ward, Victoria; Spillius, Alex; Squires, Nick (23 March 2011). [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8402899/Libya-Gaddafi-compound-attacked-after-air-force-destroyed.html "Libya: Gaddafi Compound Attacked After Air Force 'Destroyed']. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 31 March 2011.</ref> *Pro-Gaddafi forces re-entered Misrata and attacked its main hospital.<ref>Staff (23 March 2011). [http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/03/23/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T1 "Coalition Airstrikes Continue Thursday in Tripoli"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 31 March 2011.</ref>
===24 March: NATO takes command of naval operations=== *Fourteen [[Tomahawk (missile)|Tomahawk missiles]] were launched overnight in Libya by the allies, according to a spokesman for the [[United States Africa Command|US Africa Command]] in Germany. *Fighting in both Ajdabiya and Misrata continued. Tanks re-entered Misrata after previously retreating. The government attempted to capture Misrata's port with naval warships, but witnesses claimed they retreated. The coalition planned to step up air strikes on Ajdabiya and government positions, and was beginning to coordinate with rebels.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/25/world/africa/25libya.html?_r=1|work=The New York Times|last1=Bumiller|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Kirkpatrick|first2=David D.|title=Libya No-Fly Zone To Be Led by NATO|date=24 March 2011|accessdate=16 October 2011}}</ref> *A French fighter, destroyed Libyan pro-Gaddafi [[Soko G-2 Galeb]] single-engine military trainer aircraft which was breaking the no-fly zone.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/03/24/french-jets-reportedly-shoot-libyan-warplane-qaddafi-violates-fly-zone/|publisher=Fox News|title=U.S. Welcomes NATO's Decision To Enforce No-Fly Zone Over Libya|date=24 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> *A member of the opposition forces claimed a major success – killing thirty government snipers in Misrata. He also said that all Libyan government military vessels have abandoned the port.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Karouny, Mariam |author2=Tanner, Adam |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/24/us-libya-misrata-idUSTRE72N7GS20110324|agency=Reuters|title=Libya Rebels Say Regain Port, Kill Snipers in Misrata|date=24 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> *The [[Al Jufra Air Base]] was bombed by French aircraft.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/french-jets-destroy-libyan-aircraft-target-arms-flow/767044/|title=French Jets Destroy Libyan Aircraft, Target Arms Flow|agency=Associated Press|work=The Indian Express |location=India|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> Libyan Deputy Foreign Minister [[Khaled Kaim]] stated that the base was struck before dawn.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Dagher, Sam |author2=Hodge, Nathan |author3=Solomon, Jay |author4=Fidler, Stephen |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704425804576219913829478464.html|work=The Wall Street Journal|title=NATO To Enforce No-Fly Zone Over Libya|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> *A spokesman for the anti-Gaddafi forces said that Gaddafi troops in Ajdabiya were trying to surrender. Col. Ahmad Omar Bani stated that the anti-Gaddafi forces "received information from freedom fighters in Ajdabiya" saying "some Gaddafi fighters have offered to leave their tanks".<ref>{{cite news|author1=Branigin, William |author2=Wilson, Scott |author3=Bahrampouurl, Tara |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/french_jets_shoot_down_libyan_plane_bomb_air_base/2011/03/24/ABleqsPB_story.html?wprss=rss_homepage|title=NATO Moves Toward Command of Libya Operations; French Jets Hit Plane, Air Base|work=The Washington Post|date=24 March 2011|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> *NATO took command of the naval arms embargo.<ref name="globalpost03252011"/>
===25 March: NATO takes command of air operations=== *The United Arab Emirates committed six F-16 and six Mirage fighters to help enforce the no-fly zone over Libya.<ref name="globalpost03252011">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/africa/110325/libya-gaddafi-uae-nato-airstrikes|publisher=[[GlobalPost]]|title=UAE Sends Warplanes to Libya as NATO Takes Command|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/uae-commits-12-planes-to-libya-action/story-e6frf7jx-1226028340690|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|work=Herald Sun|title=UAE Commits 12 Planes to Libya Action|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *Western warplanes bombed Gaddafi's tanks and artillery in eastern Libya to try to break a battlefield stalemate and help rebels take the strategic town of [[Ajdabiya]]. French and British jets bombed targets near Ajdabiya the eastern town overnight, including government forces' artillery.<ref name="bbcGadafiArmsVolonteers">{{cite news|title=Libyan Leader 'Arming Volunteers'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12864460|work=BBC News|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *Gaddafi was said to be arming volunteers to fight the uprising against his rule.<ref name="bbcGadafiArmsVolonteers"/> *CNN reported that Canadian Lt. Gen. [[Charlie Bouchard]] was to command the NATO military air and sea operations under the name [[Operation Unified Protector]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Wallace, Kamal|date=25 March 2011|title=Libya Developments: NATO Agrees in Principle To Protect Civilians|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/03/25/libya-live-blog-uae-to-support-enforce-no-fly-zone/?hpt=T1&hpt=T2|publisher=CNN |accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *[[Abdul Ati al-Obeidi]], a former prime-minister of the Gaddafi government, stated that the Gaddafi government was open to talks with the pro-democracy rebels and accept political reforms, possibly including elections.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/03/25/libya-rebels-gadhafi-325.html|title=Libya Ready To Talk with Rebels: Former PM|agency=Associated Press|work=CBC News|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref>
==Late March rebel offensive (26–28 March)== {{main|Late March 2011 Libyan rebel offensive}}
===26 March=== *Rebel forces recaptured Ajdabiya after Gaddafi forces retreated<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/27/world/africa/27libya.html?_r=1&hp|title=Qaddafi Forces Pull Back as Rebels Retake Ajdabiya|work=The New York Times|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=26 March 2011|author1=Fahim, Kareem |author2=Kirkpatrick, David D. }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/03/26/libya-rebels.html|title=Libyan Rebels Regain Ajdabiya|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> and with little threat also captured [[Brega]];<ref>{{cite web|author1=Kiley, Sam |author2=Hurdurl, Emma |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Video-Libyan-Rebels-Retake-Brega-And-Ajdabiyah-After-Gaddafi-Forces-Flee-Amid-Coalition-Airstrikes/Article/201103415960556?lpos=World_News_Top_Stories_Header_3&lid=ARTICLE_15960556_Video%3A_Libyan_Rebels_Retake_Brega_And_Ajdabiyah_After_Gaddafi_Forces_Flee_Amid_Coalition_Airstrikes_|title=Libyan Rebels Push West To Capture Brega|publisher = [[Sky News]]|date=27 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> they also advanced towards Ra's Lanuf.<ref name="AJblog25-26march"/> *The outskirts of Misrata were hit by airstrikes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12776418|work=BBC News |title=Libya Air Raid 'Killed Civilians'|date=31 March 2011}}</ref> *Benghazi resident [[Iman al-Obeidi]] entered a Tripoli hotel, showed bruises and scars to foreign journalists and stated that she had been sworn at, tied up, urinated on and raped by fifteen pro-Gaddafi security officers, who had detained her for two days (photos:<ref name="ThReut_Eman_Obaidi_photos">[[Thomson Reuters]] photos: [http://www.daylife.com/photo/08o29vLgyJ9NE] [http://www.daylife.com/photo/05cW9OC2wOeSy] [http://www.daylife.com/photo/01JIfBD25j4HU] [http://www.daylife.com/photo/09vSfh39V1bIu]</ref>).<ref name="ThReut_Eman_Obaidi">{{cite news|title=Woman Cries for Help, Says Abused by Gaddafi Men|date=26 March 2011|agency=Reuters|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE72P05120110326?sp=true|accessdate=9 April 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xTJPEyqe|archivedate=26 March 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref> Pro-Gaddafi security officers assaulted several journalists and removed the woman from the hotel. The security officers said that they were taking al-Obaidi to a hospital. Al-Obaidi said she was being taken to prison.<ref name="ThReut_Eman_Obaidi"/> Charles Clover, a journalist with the ''[[Financial Times]]'' who attempted to defend her from Gaddafi's security forces, was deported from Libya. Clover said that he had been told the night before to leave because of what Libyan government officials said were "inaccuracies in his reporting".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/27/world/middleeast/27tripoli.html?_r=1|work=The New York Times|author=Kirkpatrick, David D.|title=Libyan Woman Struggles To Tell Journalists of Her Rape by Qaddafi Militia|date=26 March 2011}}</ref> *[[Bilgasim Al-Ganga]], number three in pro-Gaddafi forces, was said to have been detained by anti-Gaddafi forces.<ref name="AJblog25-26march">Staff (25 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/live-blog-libya-march-26 "Live Blog Libya – 26 March"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *Gaddafi's forces heavily bombard Misrata, sometimes targeting residences. One family was reported killed by such a blast. Gunners on rooftops shot at anyone who went out onto the street.<ref name="AJblog25-26march"/> *The French army issued its eighth press release on [[Opération Harmattan]] where it stated that at least five [[Soko G-2 Galeb]] fighter planes and two [[Mil Mi-24]] attack helicopters that were preparing attack in the Az Zintan and Misrata regions were shot down in the last twenty-four hours.<ref>[[Press release]] (29 March 2011). [http://www.defense.gouv.fr/operations/actualites/libye-point-de-situation-operation-harmattan-n-8 "''Libye : point de situation opération Harmattan n°8''"] (in French). [[Ministry of Defence (France)|French Ministry of Defense]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> They were making further analyses to have a more-precise assessment.
===27 March=== *Rebel fighters took control of the small town of [[Uqayla]] and the oil town of Ra's Lanuf.<ref name="fourtowns">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12873434|title=Rebels Take Ras Lanuf, Brega , Uqayla, Bin Jawa|work=BBC News|date=27 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *They also recaptured [[Bin Jawad]], a hamlet another {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=on}} to the west as they moved towards Sirte, Gaddafi's hometown.<ref>Staff (27 March 2011). [http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/World/Story/STIStory_649954.html "Libyan Rebels Retake Hamlet of Bin Jawad"]. [[Agence France-Presse]] (via ''[[The Straits Times]]''). Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> With the capture of Bin Jawad, the rebels regained all the ground in the east they lost to the pro-Gaddafi counter-offensive in the days prior to the imposition of the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973|UN-mandated no-fly zone]].<ref name="fourtowns"/> *Rebel forces claimed to advance further along the coast, taking the town of [[Nofaliya]], {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} from Sirte. Rebels said they planned to halt their advance there overnight as pro-Gaddafi forces were supposedly stationed {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=on}} down the road ready to defend Sirte.<ref name=rec1 /> *NATO said it had agreed to take over command of the military operation that was enforcing UN resolutions on Libya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12876696|work=BBC News|title=Libya: Nato Assumes Control of Military Operation|date=27 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *Eight people were killed and twenty-four wounded in Misrata as pro-Gaddafi forces fired mortars while advancing towards the city from the west.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/27/libya-misrata-toll-idUSLDE72Q0LP20110327|agency=Reuters|author=Gumuchian, Marie-Louise|title=Eight People Killed in Misrata Attack – Resident|date=27 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *The rebels signed an oil export deal with Qatar, and announced that shipments of crude would start in "less than a week".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12875810|title=Libyan Rebels 'Sign Oil Export Deal with Qatar'|work=BBC News|date=27 March 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref>
===28 March=== *[[National Transitional Council]] spokesman Shamsi Abdul Molah made the incorrect claim that the rebel forces had captured Sirte.<ref>Knight, Ben; Cowan, Jane; Staffs (29 March 2011). [http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/28/3176068.htm "Rebels Held Outside Gaddafi's Home Town"]. [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]. Retrieved 1 April 2011.</ref><ref>Staff (28 March 2011). [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/03/201132681812362552.html "Libyan Rebels Facing Tough Fight for Sirte"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 28 March 2011.</ref> *Pro-Gaddafi troops used [[BM-21 Grad|Grad]] [[multiple rocket launcher|multi-rocket launchers]] to bombard Az Zintan from the north.<ref>Adetunji, Jo; Gabbat, Adam (28 March 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/mar/28/libya-arab-unrest-live-blog "Libya and Middle East Unrest  Monday 28 March Part 1"]. ''News Blog'' (blog of ''[[The Guardian]]''). Retrieved 1 April 2011.</ref> *Al Jazeera reported that pro-Gaddafi soldiers in the town of [[Jalu]], some {{convert|200|km|mi|abbr=on}} south of [[Ajdabiya]], surrendered to rebel forces.<ref name="AJblog27-28march">Staff (27 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-28 "Libya Live Blog – 28 March"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 28 March 2011.</ref> *Agence France-Presse reported that the rebels' advance on Sirte had been halted about {{convert|137|km|abbr=off}} from the edge of Sirte by pro-Gaddafi forces. The opposition forces seized [[Nofaliya]]<ref>Blair, Edmund (28 March 2011). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/28/us-libya-east-nawfaliyah-idUSTRE72R1J720110328 "Libya Rebels Take Another Town on Advance West: TV"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 28 March 2011.</ref> and were advancing towards an area called the Red Valley, but found it to be full of mines. Fighting was ongoing near Nofaliya.<ref name="AJblog27-28march"/> *Al Jazeera reported that Qatar became the third state (after France and Portugal) to recognize the NTC as the only official government of Libya.<ref name="AJblog27-28march"/> *Pro-Gaddafi forces heavily bombard Misrata with tank shells and mortars from the north and northwest. Pro-Gaddafi snipers continued to shoot the city's residents. About 4,000 migrant workers, mostly Egyptians, were waiting by Misrata's port to be evacuated.<ref name="AJblog27-28march"/> *By evening, the rebels had advanced to about {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=on}} from Sirte.<ref>Quinn, Ben (28 March 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/mar/28/libya-military-action-live-updates "Libya and Middle East Unrest – Live Updates]. ''News Blog'' (blog of ''[[The Guardian]]''). Retrieved 1 April 2011.</ref> *UK jets bombed ammunition bunkers in southern Libya. The [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|UK Defence Ministry]] also stated that several tanks and armoured vehicles were also destroyed, including "22 tanks, armoured vehicles and artillery pieces in the vicinity of Ajdabiya and Misrata".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jsMMSvLSX9vIf0QJNWT0_EjmlhCA?docId=CNG.2bf80f7e0d48e79cc0cac11cdf4e053e.4b1|title=British Jets Bomb Tanks, Ammunition Bunkers in Libya|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]])|date=28 March 2011|accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref>
==Second loyalist offensive (29–31 March)==
===29 March=== *Pro-Gaddafi troops used heavy weaponry to force the rebels to retreat from Nofaliya towards Bin Jawad.<ref name="BBC-2011-03-29">Staff (29 March 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12892798 "Libya: Gaddafi Troops Push Rebels Back from Bin Jawad"]. BBC News. Retrieved 29 March 2011.</ref> *A US [[Lockheed P-3 Orion]] fired on a Libyan 12-meter patrol vessel after it launched missiles at merchant ships in the port of Misrata "to stop them from firing into the port, harming civilians and damaging other vessels". A US [[A-10 Thunderbolt II]] also fired on two smaller Libyan vessels traveling with the larger ship, destroying one and forcing the other to be abandoned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ih00SjajZrRqzoKtRYk6WrIfBCjA?docId=4feb676e61444623b9f057ccec371a6f|title=US Aircraft Engage Libyan Coastguard Vessel|publisher=Associated Press (via [[Google News]])|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref> *[[United States Navy|US Navy]] [[Vice Admiral]] [[William E. Gortney|Bill Gortney]], [[Director of the Joint Staff|US Joint Staff Director]], confirmed the US had employed "A-10s and [[AC-130]]s over the weekend".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/29/3176341.htm?section=justin|title=US Gunships Blast Gaddafi's Troops|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref> *The mother of [[Iman al-Obeidi]] said she had been asked to convince her daughter to retract the allegations in return for her freedom and cash or a new home. "Last night at 3, they called from Gaddafi's compound and asked me to convince my daughter Eman to change what she said, and we will set her free immediately and you can take anything you and your children would ask for," her mother stated.<ref>{{cite news|author=Williams, Alison|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE72S0LT20110329|title=Mother 'Offered Cash' If Libya Woman Changes Story|agency=Reuters|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref> *Rebels temporarily retreated from Bin Jawad after intense mortar fire, but returned and fighting continued directly west of Bin Jawad, according to the BBC News. Later, it confirmed that the rebels had once again retreated from Bin Jawad, this time some of them as far as Ra's Lanuf.<ref name="BBC-2011-03-29"/> *The [[United States Department of Defense|US Defense Department]] said that coalition forces launched 22 Tomahawk missiles overnight, while flying 115 strike sorties.<ref>Staff (28 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-29 "Libya Live Blog – 29 March"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 29 March 2011.</ref> *US Secretary of State Clinton and an envoy from the opposition forces held talks in London.<ref>Klapper, Bradly; Burns, Robert (29 March 2011). [http://www.aolnews.com/2011/03/29/nato-commander-signs-of-al-qaida-in-libyan-rebels/?icid=maing-grid7%7Caim%7Cdl1%7Csec1_lnk3%7C52881 "Renewed US Missile Barrage Amid Libya Talks"]. Associated Press (via [[AOL News]]) Retrieved 29 March 2011.</ref>
===30 March=== *Forces loyal to Gaddafi recaptured the oil-refinery town of Ra's Lanuf forcing rebels to retreat further to the east.<ref> Lubin, Gus (30 March 2011). [http://www.businessinsider.com/libya-wednesday-march-30-2011-3 "Obama Deployed CIA Agent to Libya to Aid and Supply Rebels Weeks Ago"]. [[Business Insider]]. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref><ref> Staff (30 March 2011). [http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/03/30/143529.html "Gaddafi Forces Control Oil City of Ras Lanuf Again"]. [[Al Arabiya]]. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref><ref> Blair, Edmund (30 March 2011). [http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFWEA164620110330 "Gaddafi Forces Move East, Bombard Rebels with Rockets"]. Reuters. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref> The coalition then began launching air-strikes against Gaddafi's forces around Ra's Lanuf and on the road to Uqayla. Reporters on the ground blamed a sandstorm and low visibility from the air for the lack of air-strikes the previous day.<ref>Staff (29 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-30 "Libya Live Blog – 30 March"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref> Later during the day, rebels were pulling out of Brega to Ajdabiyah.<ref>Blair, Edmund (30 March). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/30/libya-east-retreat-idUSWEA174420110330 "Libya Rebels Beat Rapid Retreat East under Fire"]. Reuters. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref> In the evening, BBC News reported that Brega was in control of pro-Gaddafi forces and Ajdabiya was coming under attack by loyalist troops. *The UK government expelled five diplomats from the Libyan embassy in London stating that they "could pose a threat" to UK security.<ref>Staff (30 March 2011). [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23936656-five-libyan-diplomats-expelled.do "UK May Yet Arm Libyan Resistance"]. ''[[Evening Standard]]''. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref> *Rebel forces, suffering a shortage of skilled armored vehicle drivers, sent out an appeal by Free Libya radio for anyone who could drive a [[T-55]] tank to report for duty immediately.<ref name="T-55">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12906562|publisher=BBC News|title=Gaddafi Forces Push Rebels Back|date=30 March 2011|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> *It was reported that [[Central Intelligence Agency|US Central Intelligence Agency]] and [[MI6|UK MI6]] operatives were in Libya to gather intelligence for coalition airstrikes and make contacts with rebel forces.<ref>[[Mark Mazzetti|Mazzetti, Mark]]; [[Eric P. Schmitt|Schmitt, Eric]] (30 March 2011). [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/31/world/africa/31intel.html "C.I.A. in Libya Aiding Rebels, U.S. Officials Say"]. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref> *The UK government confirmed that the Libyan Foreign Minister, [[Moussa Koussa]], had resigned and defected to the UK.<ref>Staff (30 March 2011). [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/03/2011330151017941970.html "Libya's Foreign Minister Defects"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref> *The head of intelligence, the oil minister, the secretary of the [[General People's Congress (Libya)|Libyan General People's Congress]] and a deputy foreign minister also defected and escaped Libya.<ref>Staff (30 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-31 "Libya Live Blog – 31 March"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 30 March 2011.</ref>
===31 March=== {{main|Third Battle of Brega}} *Explosions reportedly shook an eastern suburb of Tripoli, as warplanes staged a raid on the Libyan capital.<ref name="AJMarch30-31blog">Staff (30 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-31 "Libya Live Blog – 31 March"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 31 March 2011.</ref> *NATO took sole command of air operations in Libya as [[Central Intelligence Agency|US Central Intelligence Agency]] operatives worked the field to connect with rebel fighters who had seen their advance toward Tripoli halted.<ref>Staff (31 March 2011). [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/03/31/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T1 "NATO Takes Over Air Operations as CIA Works the Ground in Libya"]. CNN. Retrieved 31 March 2011.</ref> *Rebels counter-attacked against Brega in an attempt to push out Gaddafi's forces.<ref>Staff (31 March 2011). [http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/africa/news/article_1629847.php/Rebels-return-to-Brega-amid-reported-defections-by-special-forces "Rebels Return to Brega Amid Reported Defections by Special Forces"]. [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] (via [[Monsters and Critics]]). Retrieved 31 March 2011.</ref> By late afternoon, coalition forces had bombed pro-Gaddafi forces near Brega. [[BBC Monitoring]] quoted a privately owned online newspaper, ''[[Libya al-Yawm]]'', that Gaddafi's forces had been pushed back to the village of Bishr, west of the city. However, it was confirmed by rebel sources that street fighting was still ongoing in Brega. By the end of the day, pro-Gaddafi forces had repelled the rebel counter-attack and were in firm control of Brega.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Chris McGreal|McGreal, Chris]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/31/libya-rebels-brega-assault-fails|work=The Guardian |location=UK |title=Libyan Rebels Deny Crisis After Assault on Brega Fail|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=1 April 2011}}</ref> *Libyan diplomat [[Ali Treki]] fled to Egypt and resigned.<ref name="AJMarch30-31blog"/> Gaddafi spoke out to those like him and called them "traitors", swearing to block their access back to the country once the war is over.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} *According to [[Al Arabiya]], Gaddafi's intelligence chief [[Abu Zayd Durda]] had fled to Tunisia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2F |title=Google Translate |publisher=Translate.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref><ref>[http://www.europapress.es%2Finternacional%2Fnoticia-libia-ex-ministro-exteriores-jefe-inteligencia-abandonan-gadafi-20110331165025.html] {{dead link|date=February 2015}}</ref> There were widespread unconfirmed reports that multiple additional high-level Gaddafi government officials were planning to defect.<ref>Staff (1 April 2011). [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/03/20113312103411544.html "More 'Defections from Gaddafi Inner Circle'"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 1 April 2011.</ref><ref>Staff (1 April 2011). [http://www.skynews.com.au/world/article.aspx?id=596019&vId="More Senior Libyans To Defect]. Sky News. 1 April 2011.</ref><ref>Staff (31 March 2011). [http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/129338/20110331/libya.htm "More High-Level Libyan Officials Reportedly Defecting"]. ''[[International Business Times]]''. Retrieved 1 April 2011.</ref> *Gaddafi's spokesman, [[Moussa Ibrahim]], downplayed Koussa's defection by claiming that the former minister is "an old man who cannot take the pressure".<ref>{{cite web|author=Radnedge, Aidan|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/859709-libya-plays-down-musa-kusa-s-british-defection|title=Libya Plays Down Musa Kusa's British Defection|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=1 April 2011}}</ref>
==Early April (1–15 April)==
===1 April=== *Gaddafi's forces intensified their attack on Misrata, using tanks, RPGs and artillery on civilian buildings.<ref name="AJblog31march-1april">Staff (31 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-1 "Libya Live Blog – 1 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 1 April 2011.</ref> *Rebel forces on the outskirts of Brega were bolstered by the arrival of a number of well-armed, seemingly well-trained soldiers in full military attire. It was not immediately clear where they were from.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Al Jazeera reported that Swedish lawmakers approved a plan to send up to eight fighter jets and one transport plane to join the NATO-led air operations over Libya.<ref name="AJblog31march-1april"/> *Seven civilians died and twenty-five were wounded in a coalition air strike on a pro-Gaddafi convoy in eastern Libya. The strike hit a truck carrying ammunition, and the resulting explosion destroyed two nearby homes.<ref>Staff (1 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12931731 "Libya Air Raid 'Killed Civilians'"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 1 April 2011.</ref> *NATO airstrikes destroyed a pro-Gaddafi military convoy attempting to enter Misrata.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Rebels said neither side could claim control of Brega, one of a string of oil towns along the Mediterranean coast that had been taken and retaken by each side in recent weeks. Warplanes flew over Brega, followed by the sound of explosions.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Golovnina, Maria |author2=Dziadosz, Alexander |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/04/01/uk-libya-idUKLDE71Q0MP20110401|agency=Reuters|title=Libyan Government Dismisses Rebels' 'Mad' Truce Offer|date=1 April 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *The Benghazi-based opposition offered a conditional ceasefire, but Gaddafi's government described its terms as "mad", saying it required the Gaddafi government to withdraw troops from cities.<ref>Staff (1 April 2011). [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/04/201141134110527219.html "Libya Government Rejects Rebel Ceasefire"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *A rebel convoy near Brega fired into the air with an anti-aircraft gun, perhaps in celebration. A NATO [[A-10 Thunderbolt II]] aircraft then returned fire and killed at least thirteen people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12944905|work=BBC News|title=Libya: Coalition Air Strike Near Brega Kills Rebels|date=2 April 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref><ref>Fahim, Kareem; [[C.J. Chivers|Chivers, C.J.]] (2 April 2011). [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/03/world/africa/03libya.html "NATO Airstrike Reportedly Kills Rebels in Libya"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 11 June 2011.</ref>
===2 April=== *In the early morning, rebels managed to break through the eastern gate of Brega. They took control of most of the city from loyalist forces before loyalist artillery hit the rebels and by mid-afternoon the opposition forces had retreated from the town and were regrouping at a checkpoint to the east of the city.<ref>Dziadosz, Alexander (3 April 2011). [http://www.ottawacitizen.com/story_print.html?id=4546979 "NATO-Led Air Strike Kills 13 Libyan Rebels"]. [[Reuters]] (via ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]''). Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> Later, the rebels managed once again to enter the town and took control of a part of it. However, a large number of Gaddafi's forces were holed up at the university<ref>Staff (2 April 2011). [http://www.channel4.com/news/libya-coalition-air-strike-kills-rebels-near-brega "Libya: Coalition Air Strike Kills Rebels Near Brega"]. [[Channel 4 News]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> and the rebels were still not able to get into the city center.<ref>Staff (3 April 2011). [http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle09.asp?xfile=data/international/2011/April/international_April129.xml&section=international "Libya Rebels Battle Gaddafi Forces in Oil Town"]. [[Reuters]] (via ''[[Khaleej Times]]''). Retrieved 9 August 2011.</ref> *[[AVAAZ.org]] created a petition with the goal of convincing Turkey to request the Gaddafi government to free al-Obeidi. *Libya's rebel council named what it called a "crisis team", including a new armed-forces head, which was to administer parts of the country it was helping in its struggle to topple Gaddafi.<ref>Staff (2 April 2011). [http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/04/02/uk-libya-rebels-idUKTRE7311YV20110402 "Libyan Rebels Name Team To Run Areas They Control"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 2 April 2011.</ref> *In Misrata, after weeks of shelling and encirclement, pro-Gaddafi forces appeared to be gradually loosening the rebels' hold there, despite Western air strikes on pro-Gaddafi targets. The rebels said they still controlled the city center and the sea port, but Gaddafi's forces had pushed into the center along the main thoroughfare.<ref>Golovnina, Maria (2 April 2011). [http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/libya-shells-town-in-west-rebels-name-crisis-team/ "Libya Shells Town in West as Rebels Name 'Crisis Team'"]. [[Reuters]] (via [[AlertNet]]). Retrieved 3 April 2011.</ref>
===3 April=== *In the morning, the rebels advanced in an attempt to take Brega's university campus only to be ambushed and came up on roadside mines which led to a rebel retreat 30 to 35 kilometers from the town. Some of the better-trained rebels were still left behind on Brega's outskirts locked in skirmishes and artillery duels with Gaddafi's forces in the town.<ref>{{cite news|date=3 April 2011|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/battle-for-brega-rages-after-ambush-20110403-1ctek.html|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (via ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'')|author=Burleigh, March|title=Battle for Brega Rages After Ambush|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/03/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T2#|publisher=CNN |title=Sources: Gadhafi Forces Strike Misrata Clinic; Shelling Heard in City|date=3 April 2011|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> *Gaddafi's forces shelled Zintan, southwest of Tripoli.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Water and electricity shortages worsened in Misrata, particularly on the outskirts of the city. The area near the central-city hospital was bombarded. *The US agreed to NATO's request for a 48-hour extension of US participation in coalition air strikes against targets in Libya.<ref>Lardner, Richard (3 April 2011). [http://www.militarytimes.com/news/2011/04/ap-us-extends-libya-airstrike-role-by-48-hours-040311/?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter "U.S. Extends Libya Airstrike Role by 48 Hours"]. [[Associated Press]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *The Chairperson of the African Union traveled to Europe to discuss the Libyan crisis.<ref>Press release (3 April 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/chairperson-travels-europe-discuss-libyan-crisis "Chairperson Travels to Europe To Discuss Libyan Crisis"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 16 August 2011.</ref>
===4 April=== *The Chairperson of the African Union was received in London by the Foreign Secretary.<ref>Press release (5 April 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/chairperson-received-london-foreign-secretary-mr-william-hague-and-other-uk-government-offic "Chairperson Received in London by the Foreign Secretary, Mr. William Hague and other UK Government Officials"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. 16 August 2011.</ref> *Libyan rebels again advanced towards the oil town of Brega.<ref>Staff (4 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12957681 "Libya: Rebels Move on Brega as Gaddafi Aide Holds Talks"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *Backed by coalition airstrikes, revolutionaries pushed back into Brega and were holding the eastern part of the town. Revolutionaries reported that Gaddafi's forces were leaving land mines after withdrawing from the area around Brega's university.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Italy recognised the interim national council in Benghazi as its "only legitimate [[interlocutor (politics)|interlocutor]]" in Libya, Foreign Minister Franco Frattini said on Monday.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *In southern Libya, pro-Gaddafi forces attacked oil fields that supply the opposition-held oil terminal in [[Tobruk]].<ref>Staff (3 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-4 "Libya Live Blog – 4 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *A resident of a town in the [[Jabal al Gharbi District|Jabal al Gharbi]] area, about {{convert|230|km|abbr=off}} southwest of Tripoli, told Agence France-Presse that Gaddafi's forces fired Grad rockets at the town of [[Nalut]].{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}
===5 April=== *The [[Turkish Navy]] intercepted a private ship from Benghazi that was carrying weapons, ammunition, and medical supplies to the people of Misrata. The Turkish navy refused to allow the ship to land at Misrata.<ref>Bengali, Shashank (6 April 2011). [http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/11096/1137225-82.stm "Libyan Rebel Leader Slams NATO Over Response"]. [[McClatchy Newspapers]] (via ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''). Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *Rebels pulled back, after a night of fighting, from inside Brega to the outskirts. They re-assembled at the eastern edge to prepare for further fighting.<ref>Staff (5 April 2011). [http://content.usatoday.com/dist/custom/gci/InsidePage.aspx?cId=citizen-times&sParam=45773916.story "Libyan Rebel Leader Says NATO Isn't Doing Enough"]. [[Associated Press]] (via ''[[USA Today]]''). Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> At that point, loyalist artillery started firing on the rebels which led to them pulling back from Brega's outskirts in a panicked retreat.<ref>Staff (5 April 2011). [http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/05/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T2# "Libyan Rebel Leaders Say They Are 'Disappointed' by NATO's Efforts"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref><ref>Staff (5 April 2011). [http://www.sundaytimes.lk/index.php/world-news/6211-nato-warplanes-attack-kadhafi-forces-near-brega-afp "NATO Warplanes Attack Kadhafi Forces Near Brega: AFP"]. [[Agence France-Presse]] (via ''[[The Sunday Times (Sri Lanka)|The Sunday Times]]''). Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> After that, an eight-vehicle military convoy, belonging to Gaddafi's forces, approached the rebel's positions, {{convert|30|km|abbr=off}} east of Brega; it was hit by air strikes destroying two vehicles while the rest turned back. An Agence France-Presse reporter confirmed there were no fatalities among loyalist forces in the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zawya.com/Story.cfm/sidANA20110405T112215ZFVU33/Libya%20open%20to%20reform,%20rebels%20pushed%20back |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020051314/http://www.zawya.com/Story.cfm/sidANA20110405T112215ZFVU33/Libya%20open%20to%20reform,%20rebels%20pushed%20back |archivedate=20 October 2012 }}</ref> *An Al Jazeera correspondent reported that the defected 36th "AsSaiqa" battalion was attacking from the south of Brega in the desert. They were launching a heavy attack against Gaddafi's forces using Grad missiles. They had managed to push west once more towards the area of Arbaeen which caused Gaddafi's forces to retreat. It was difficult to verify casualties, but four shells landed directly in an area where revolutionaries were congregated earlier. Ambulances were seen rushing to that area and they had not come back since.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Defected interior minister and Major General [[Abdul Fatah Younis]] criticized NATO by saying it was not doing enough, and that "civilians are dying every day". Younis talked about how sewage was being re-routed into water wells in Misrata by Gaddafi's forces, and that water supplies were running desperately short in Misrata.<ref>Staff (4 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-5 "Libya Live Blog – 5 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref>
===6 April=== *Al Jazeera reported that the rebels in Nalut and Zintan entered [[Yafran]] and helped their allies there to fight against Gaddafi loyalists. Armed with [[Kalashnikovs|Kalashnikov]] rifles, they were able to drive Gaddafi's forces from Yafran.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *An escaped prisoner reported that rebel soldiers captured by pro-Gaddafi forces were being tortured in an underground prison in Sirte.<ref>Staff (5 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-6 "Libya Live Blog – 6 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *There was heavy fighting along the coastal road between Ajdabiya and Brega, Reuters reported. Gaddafi loyalists had been resupplied with ammunition. The rebels were, at that point, some {{convert|20|km|abbr=off}} away from Brega. *The UK moved four [[Eurofighter Typhoon|Typhoon jets]] from policing the Libyan no-fly zone to ground-attack roles following opposition criticism that NATO forces failed to protect Misrata. In a statement, the UK defence ministry said the move aimed at "further bolstering NATO's ground attack capability".{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Rebels and loyalists continued to clash on the Brega–Ajdabiya road.<ref>Staff (6 April 2011). [http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/06/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T2# "Gadhafi Asks Obama To End NATO Bombing"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *During the early morning, a ship carrying 300 migrants from Libya capsized in rough seas off Italy. Survivors told of trying to reach rescue boats as those unable to swim screamed in the darkness and pulled one another under water. There was speculation that 250 people of the 300 died. If confirmed, it would be the deadliest crossing to Italy in recent memory and the worst refugee disaster since a wave of migrants began arriving in Italy in January after popular revolts in Tunisia, Egypt and Libya. The [[Corps of the Port Captaincies – Coast Guard|Italian Coast Guard]] rescued forty-eight people later in the day and a fishing boat picked up three after the vessel began taking on water shortly after 1 a.m.<ref>Staff (7 April 2011). [http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2011/apr/07/TDMAIN07-ship-carrying-libyans-capsizes-250-missin-ar-955859/ "Ship Carrying Libyans Capsizes; 250 Missing"]. ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]''. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *The Chairperson of the African Union was received in Rome by [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Italy)|Italian Foreign Minister]] [[Franco Frattini]].<ref>Press release (7 August 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/chairperson-received-rome-italian-minister-foreign-affairs-mr-franco-frattini "Chairperson Received in Rome by Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr. Franco Frattini"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 16 August 2011.</ref>
===7 April=== *A Libyan rebel tank convoy was mistakenly hit by a NATO air strike killing thirteen and wounding many.<ref>Staff (7 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12997181 "Libyan Rebels Near Ajdabiya 'Killed in Nato Air Strike'"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> British admiral and NATO commander Russell Harding refused to apologize for this attack, saying that "until yesterday we didn't even know that the rebels possess any tanks", his task was to protect civilians and "it is not our task .. to improve communications with the rebels".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,755828,00.html|title=Neue Gaddafi-Taktik erschwert Angriffe der Nato|language=German|trans_title=Gaddafi makes new tactics of NATO attacks|work=Der Spiegel|date=4 April 2011|accessdate=16 October 2011}}</ref> *Following the attack, Gaddafi loyalists chased the rebel forces to Ajdabiya, and both civilians and some rebels were on the verge of retreating from the city amid rumors Gaddafi's forces were preparing for an attack.<ref>Bengali, Shashank (7 April 2011). [http://www.standard.net/topics/middle-east/2011/04/07/gadhafi-plane-evades-nato-no-fly-zone-bombs-rebel-tanks "Gadhafi Plane Evades NATO No-Fly Zone, Bombs Rebel Tanks]. [[McClatchy Newspapers]] (via ''[[Standard-Examiner]]''). Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref><ref>Staff (7 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13008384 "Rebels Retreat in Ajdabiya After 'Nato Air Strike'"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *The US might consider putting troops on the ground for a ground offensive, Army General [[Carter Ham]] said.<ref>Staff (7 April 2011). [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/04/07/501364/main20051760.shtml "Gen.: U.S. Troops Not Ideal, But May Be Considered in Libya"]. [[CBS News]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *NATO airstrikes killed two rebels and wounded ten in Brega.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8434749/Libya-Nato-airstrike-kills-rebels-in-Brega.html "Libya: Nato Airstrike 'Kills Rebels in Brega'"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. 7 April 2011. Retrieved 11 June 2011.</ref>
===8 April=== {{See also|Battle of Brega-Ajdabiya road}} *NATO confirmed it had bombed rebel tanks.<ref>Staff (8 April 2011). [http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/04/08/nato-confirms-planes-struck-libyan-rebels/ "NATO Confirms Its Planes Struck Libyan Rebels"]. [[Associated Press]] (via [[Fox News]]). Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> *[[UNICEF]] reported, based upon consistent reports from local sources, that pro-Gaddafi snipers in Misrata showed a pattern of indiscriminately targeting children. The Red Cross was sending a team on a boat to Misrata to investigate. *The [[United States Department of the Treasury|US Department of the Treasury]] announced new sanctions against five senior pro-Gaddafi persons: [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]], [[Shukri Ghanem]], [[Abdulhafid Zlitni]], [[Tohami Khaled]] and [[Bashir Saleh]].<ref name="UStreasury8april">[[Press release]] (8 April 2011). [http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/tg1131.aspx " Increasing Pressure on the Qadhafi Regime, Treasury Designates Five Senior Government Officials, Two Entities Owned or Controlled by Children of Qadhafi"]. [[United States Department of the Treasury|US Department of the Treasury]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> The US now had personal sanctions in place against sixteen people and had frozen over US$34 billion in overseas assets related to the Gaddafi government.<ref name="UStreasury8april"/> *Pro-Gaddafi's forces attacked an eastern district of Misrata. After heavy fighting, they were pushed back. Earlier, rebels tried to cut off the main road with big containers in an attempt to isolate the snipers in the city center. However, the loyalists positioned one or two tanks on the main road to counter the rebels' attempt. These tanks were disabled by the rebels, and several of Gaddafi's snipers were killed or captured. Families were seeking refuge in schools and other buildings.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}
===9 April=== *The [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] announced that its 130-cubic-metre relief shipment had arrived in Misrata.<ref>[[Press release]] (9 April 2011). [http://www.icrc.org/web/fre/sitefre0.nsf/html/libya-news-2011-04-09-eng "Libya: Reaching People in Misrata and Zawiyah"]. [[International Committee of the Red Cross]]. Retrieved 10 April 2011.</ref> *During the morning, pro-Gaddafi forces shelled the western outskirts of Ajdabiya. A Reuters correspondent reported hearing blasts and machine gun fire for around thirty minutes from the western boundary of the town, which is the gateway to Benghazi.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Despite the UN no-fly-zone policy, the rebel side used an [[Mi-24 Hind]] attack helicopter. *NATO warplanes intercepted a [[MiG-23]] fighter jet operated by an opposition pilot, forcing him to land after he violated the no-fly zone.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Several fighters were killed in Misrata; the clashes centered around the road leading to the port. NATO also attacked Gaddafi's forces in several locations.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *There was a meeting of the African Union High-Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya.<ref>Press release (11 April 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/meeting-au-high-level-ad-hoc-committee-libya "Meeting of the AU High-Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 16 August 2011.</ref>
===10 April=== *There was a visit of the African Union High Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya to Tripoli.<ref>Press release (11 April 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/visit-african-union-high%E2%80%90level-ad-hoc-committee-situation-libya-tripoli "Visit of the African Union High‐Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on the Situation in Libya to Tripoli"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 16 August 2011.</ref> *NATO announced that its [[Operation Unified Protector]] destroyed eleven [[tank]]s near Ajdabiya and fourteen near Misrata during the day.<ref>[[Press release]] (10 April 2011). [http://www.nato.int/cps/en/SID-EE6963E7-FF6D4E00/natolive/news_72199.htm "NATO Strikes Hit Gaddafi Forces Around Adjabiya and Misratah"]. [[NATO]]. Retrieved 12 April 2011.</ref> *Anti-Gaddafi fighters said NATO airstrikes helped them hold Ajdabiya and drive Gaddafi's forces out during the weekend's attack.<ref>Staff (10 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-10 "Libya Live Blog – 10 April"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410000000/http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-10 |date=10 April 2011 }}. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 12 April 20911.</ref> They said the loyalist incursion in western Ajdabiya lasted perhaps twenty-four hours and took thirteen civilian lives. *The BBC News reported that an African Union mission had arrived in Libya to try to negotiate a ceasefire between the rebels and the loyalists.<ref>Staff (11 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13029165 "Libya: Gaddafi Government Accepts Truce Plan, Says Zuma]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 12 April 2011.</ref>
===11 April=== *NATO announced that its Operation Unified Protector destroyed eleven tanks on 11 April, twenty-five tanks on 10 April and forty-nine since 9 April.<ref>[[Press release]] (11 April 2011). [http://www.nato.int/cps/en/SID-3FC0F50B-30D81538/natolive/news_72268.htm "NATO Strikes Further Reduce Pro-Gaddafi Forces Capacity"]. [[NATO]]. Retrieved 12 April 2011.</ref> *A rebel spokesman in Misrata said they saw no evidence of a ceasefire. Instead, pro-Gaddafi forces seemed to be stepping up their attack on the city, using Grad rockets for the first time.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} Intense street fighting continued. *The BBC News reported that the rebels rejected a peace plan presented by the African Union. The rebels said they were rejecting the truce because it did not include plans for Gaddafi to step down.<ref>Staff (11 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13035501 "Libya: Benghazi Rebels Reject African Union Truce Plan"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 12 April 2011.</ref>
===12 April=== *On 12 April, rebel fighters claimed they took position {{convert|40|km|abbr=off}} west of the strategic town of Ajdabiya after clashes with pro-Gaddafi forces that left at least three dead. Pro-Gaddafi forces bombarded the western entrance to Ajdabiya, a witness reported. Eight blasts, apparently from artillery, were heard by the witness. *Reuters reported that pro-Gaddafi forces had attacked Zintan. The attacks for the most part were random firing from north of the town. *Reuters also reported that rebels in Misrata repelled two attacks from pro-Gaddafi forces. The fighting was on Tripoli Street, which leads to the city center, and Nak el Theqeel Street, which leads to the city's port.
===13 April=== *NATO conducted air strikes against munitions bunkers {{convert|13|km|abbr=off}} from Tripoli. *The Pentagon said on 13 April that US fighter jets had conducted strikes on Libyan air defenses even after NATO took command over operations in Libya. [[United States Department of Defense|US Defense Department]] spokesman Colonel David Lapan said US aircraft had been dropping bombs on Libyan air defenses following the full handover earlier this month to NATO control of the coalition operation there. US officials had previously said that the US was limiting its current role in the operation to support and patrolling of a no-fly zone over Libya. Lapan said the US remained in a support role.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}
===14 April=== *Pro-Gaddafi forces again pounded Misrata, targeting the port where a medical aid ship was expected to dock and destroying a cement factory and cargo containers, residents said. At least twenty people were killed and more than twenty others were wounded in a dawn attack at the port and a nearby residential area, a medical assistant told CNN.<ref>Staff (14 April 2011). [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/14/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T1 "Residents Report Fierce Fighting in Besieged Libyan City"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 14 April 2011.</ref> *Pro-Gaddafi forces fired anti-aircraft guns at NATO warplanes from positions in central Tripoli. Coalition jets appeared to have increased the amount of sorties flown over the capital and could be heard flying over throughout the morning and early afternoon. A NATO strike on Tripoli damaged parts of a university complex. Smoke was also seen on a military base, which was the target of the attack. Several people were injured.<ref>Staff (14 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13089452 "Libya: Several Hurt in Nato Air Strike on Tripoli"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 15 April 2011.</ref> *There was fierce fighting at the front line, halfway between Brega and Ajdabiya. Agence France-Presse reported that a convoy of sixty opposition vehicles came under heavy artillery and mortar fire. They rushed reinforcements to the front line between their territory in the east and the mainly government-held west. The AFP correspondent counted some 100 rebel vehicles heading to the front. *The leaders of the [[BRICS]] nations – Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa – believe the situation in Libya should be resolved through diplomatic means, Russian President Medvedev said. "Like the other BRICS nations, Russia is deeply concerned by events in Libya and the civilian deaths there", Medvedev said after a BRICS summit in [[Sanya]], China.
===15 April=== *A ship with nearly 1,200 Asian and African migrants, many in bad shape after weeks with little food or water, left Misrata on Friday for Benghazi, the [[International Organization for Migration]] said. The chartered Greek vessel, ''Ionian Spirit'', managed to unload 400 tonnes of aid supplies in Misrata overnight despite shelling on 14 April, the international aid agency said.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *NATO launched three new air strikes in and around Tripoli. They struck a missile battery and two other targets.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Rebels claimed to have gained control over eastern Brega after heavy clashes.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *NATO strikes hit the area of al-Assah, about {{convert|170|km|abbr=off}} west of Tripoli.<ref>Staff (15 April 2011). [http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE73E22620110415 "NATO Strikes Hit Libya's al-Assah Area – State TV"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 15 April 2011.</ref> *Pro-Gaddafi forces unleashed heavy shelling on Misrata, pushing troops and tanks into the rebel-held western city, a witness said.<ref>Staff (15 April 2011). [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/04/15/501364/main20054299.shtml "Qaddafi Forces Intensify Assault on Misrata]. [[CBS News]]. Retrieved 17 April 2011.</ref> *At the UN, Russia, China and India prevented sanctions from being imposed on Libyan state television.<ref>Staff (14 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-15 "Libya Live Blog – 15 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 17 April 2011.</ref>
==Late April (16–30 April)==
