===16 April=== *Al Jazeera reported that there was still fighting going on in Brega, and the previous-day's attack had been repelled with heavy casualties on the opposition side.<ref>Staff (15 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-16 "Libya Live Blog – 16 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 18 April 2011.</ref> *Sirte and Al-Hira were target areas in air strikes by NATO.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} Rebel media claimed that: *Pro-Gaddafi forces launched a Grad rocket attack on an industrial area in Misrata in the morning.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Rebel forces advanced to the oil town of Brega, hoping to bring engineers to repair damage to the refineries and the terminal. The officer who reported this also attributed the advance to NATO airstrikes. However, by afternoon it was confirmed that the assault was repelled, with rebels not managing to enter the town.<ref>Hubbard, Ben (17 April 2011). [http://www.todayonline.com/World/EDC110416-0000871/Libyan-rebels-say-theyve-reached-oil-town-again "More Shelling in Rebel-Held City in Western Libyan"]. [[Associated Press]] (via ''[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]''). Retrieved 18 April 2011.</ref>
===17 April=== *An Al Jazeera correspondent, from just outside Ajdabiya, reported that pro-Gaddafi troops had outflanked the body of rebel fighters on the edge of Brega and attacked Ajdabiya from the south. A sandstorm stopped NATO from targeting pro-Gaddafi forces, allowing the forces to overturn the rebel advances from the past few days.<ref>16 April 2011. [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-17 "Libya Live Blog – 17 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 18 April 2011.</ref> After a few hours of skirmishes, pro-Gaddafi forces forward units, engaging rebels on the western outskirts of Ajdabiya, pulled back. In the afternoon more than thirty vehicles of rebel reinforcements arrived in Ajdabiya.<ref>17 April 2011. [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/04/2011417192411769432.html "Libyan Rebels Resist Ajdabiya Assault"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 18 April 2011.</ref> *Reuters reported that nearly 4,000 Libyans had fled from the Western Mountains region to Tunisia in the past ten days. "They are in thousands. Hundreds arrived a few minutes ago. They are from several areas including Nalut, Yafran and Rajban," a Tunisian involved in helping Libyans arriving in the southern Tunisian border town of [[Dehiba]] said by phone. Residents fled the region because of shelling, fighting and threats by pro-Gaddafi forces.<ref>Dahl, Frederik (17 April 2011). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/17/us-libya-tunisia-refugees-idUSTRE73G1IJ20110417 "Libyans Flee Violence in Remote Western Area"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 18 April 2011.</ref>
===18 April=== *The humanitarian situation in Misrata worsened amid more shelling on the city and measures to get medical care were becoming increasingly desperate, an opposition spokesman said.<ref name="CNN18april">Staff (19 April 2011). [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/18/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T1 "Spokesman: Horror in Misrata Grows with Fresh Shelling, Little Aid"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 19 April 2011.</ref> *The [[Permanent Representative of the United Kingdom to the United Nations|UK Mission to the UN]] announced that it would help 5,000 people trapped in Misrata "escape the besieged city and will provide vital medical assistance to those who remain in towns across western Libya," intending to evacuate foreign workers from the port.<ref name="CNN18april"/> *Three army officers, including a captain and a colonel defected to Tunisia by boat along with twenty Libyan civilians.<ref>Staff (17 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-18 "Libya Live Blog – 18 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 19 April 2011.</ref> *In anticipation of UN approval for a ground mission in Misrata, the European Union prepared 1,000 troops for the mission.<ref>Traynor, Ian (18 April 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/apr/18/libya-conflict-eu-deployment-ground-troops?CMP=twt_fd "Libya Conflict: EU Awaits UN Approval for Deployment of Ground Troops"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved 19 April 2011.</ref>
===19 April=== *[[UNICEF]] announced that at least twenty children had been killed in weeks of fighting in Misrata. Many more were injured and traumatized by what they had seen and heard. The deaths and injuries were due to shrapnel from mortar and tanks and bullet wounds. The youngest victim was nine months old and most of the children killed in the past two weeks were younger than ten, a spokeswoman said.<ref>Nebehay, Stephanie (19 April 2011). [http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE73I0G620110419 "At Least 20 Children Killed in Misrata So Far – UNICEF"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 19 April 2011.</ref> *The UK said it was expanding its presence in Libya with military advisers and the EU said it was prepared to send troops for humanitarian assistance if requested by the UN.<ref>Staff (19 April 2011). [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/19/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T2 "Britain Sending Military Team to Libya"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 20 April 2011.</ref>
===20 April=== *There was fighting on Misrata's Tripoli Street, but no shelling was taking place, an opposition fighter told Reuters.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *[[President of France|French President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] promised NTC chairman [[Mustafa Abdul Jalil]] that France would intensify air strikes on Gaddafi's army. Meanwhile, Italian Defense Minister La Russa, said that Italy would send ten army advisers to aid the rebels in Libya, after France and the UK announced they were also sending officers. *The US decided to give opposition forces "non-lethal assistance" goods worth US$25 million after assessing their capabilities and intentions. The goods are to be delivered from existing US stocks and comprise "medical supplies, uniforms, boots, tents, personal protective gear, radios" and food. *Photojournalists [[Tim Hetherington]] and [[Chris Hondros]] died in Misrata while covering the civil war.<ref>Staff (22 April 2011). [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/20/libya.journalists/index.html?hpt=T1 "Bodies of Two Photographers Killed in Libya Arrive in Benghazi"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 22 April 2011.</ref> *NTC spokesman Ghoga told a news conference in Benghazi that the council was not opposed to foreign ground forces to protect a safe haven for civilians. "If that (protecting civilians) does not come except through ground forces that will ensure this safe haven, then there is no harm in that at all."{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Heavy mortar fire in Misrata killed at least ten and injured more than 100 others. Seven Libyan civilians and a [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] doctor also died in the most recent fighting, doctors told Reuters, with about 120 people injured.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *[[Mohammed El Senussi|Crown Prince Mohammed El Senussi]] spoke in front of the [[European Parliament]] calling for more support for Libya.<ref name="Libyan Crown Prince speaks to EU Parliament" >{{Cite news|url=http://www.ecrgroup.eu/Libyan%20Crown%20Prince%20speaks%20to%20EU%20Parliament-news-308.html|title=Libyan Crown Prince Speaks to EU Parliament|publisher =[[European Conservatives and Reformists]]|accessdate=23 April 2011}}</ref>
===21 April=== {{main|Battle of Wazzin}} *Anti-Gaddafi forces expanded their control over areas of eastern and western parts of Misrata. Fighting subsided compared to previous weeks, while pro-Gaddafi forces continued to shell the city.<ref name="AJblog21april">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-21-0|title=Libya Live Blog – 21 April|date=21 April 2011|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=22 April 2011}}</ref> *Anti-Gaddafi forces took control of [[Wazzin]] on the Tunisian border after overrunning pro-Gaddafi troops.<ref name="AJblog21april"/> Roughly 100 pro-Gaddafi troops surrendered to Tunisian authorities as anti-Gaddafi forces overran Wazzin. Among the troops were thirteen army officers, including a general.<ref name="AJblog21april"/> The Tunisian new agency reported that the soldiers had "defected" upon entering Tunisia.<ref>Staff (21 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-africa-13156199?PDA=1%252525253F53 "Libya: Rebels 'Capture Wazin Post' on Tunisian Border"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 22 April 2011.</ref> However, all of the 100 soldiers returned from Tunisia into Libya the next day.<ref>Staff (21 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-22 "Libya Live Blog – 22 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 22 April 2011.</ref> *US Defense Secretary Gates announced that the US had made two armed [[General Atomics MQ-1 Predator|Predator drones]] available to the NATO-led bombing effort.<ref>Staff (21 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13166441 "US Deploys Armed Drones over Libya – Robert Gates"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 22 April 2011.</ref><ref>Zirulnick, Ariel (22 April 2011). [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2011/0422/US-to-begin-drone-strikes-in-Libya "US To Begin Drone Strikes in Libya]". ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''. Retrieved 22 April 2011.</ref>
===22 April=== *Anti-Gaddafi forces managed to clear the center of Misrata from snipers, and secure some vital buildings amidst fighting over the city<ref>Georgy, Michael (22 April 2011). [http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE73L0A120110422?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 "Rebels Savour Victory after Clearing Snipers"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 22 April 2011.</ref><ref>Farmer, Ben (22 April 2011). [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8468816/Libya-Misurata-rebels-dislodge-Gaddafi-snipers.html "Libya: Misurata Rebels Dislodge Gaddafi Snipers"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 22 April 2011.</ref> *Pro-Gaddafi forces attacked an opposition-held oil pumping station, officials from an oil company said. One witness said eight people were killed in the attack. The attack could delay efforts to restart production from the rebel-controlled Sarir and Messla oil fields, suspended after an earlier raid two weeks ago. The extent of the damage was not yet known.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *A Qatari military aircraft arrived in Tunisia to build an advanced field hospital in the Al-Zahabiyah area, near the border with Libya, to treat people injured in Gaddafi brigades attacks. The plane carried a medical team, the first batch of equipment the hospital, 25 tonnes of medicines, medical supplies and ambulances.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Pro-Gaddafi forces withdrew from Misrata and claim they will allow the tribal leaders to deal with anti-Gaddafi forces. Meanwhile, NATO continued its air strikes on Tripoli.<ref>Staff (22 April 2011). [http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/22/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T2 "Official: 3 Dead in Airstrike at Gadhafi's Compound"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 23 April 2011.</ref>
===23 April=== *NATO conducted air strikes on Tripoli in the early hours. Agence France-Presse reporters said they heard several explosions after planes flew over, followed by anti-aircraft fire.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *An opposition spokesman in Misrata said the city was freed from pro-Gaddafi's forces on 23 April after a siege of nearly two months. There was no independent confirmation, but pro-Gaddafi troops captured by anti-Gaddafi forces in Misrata said the army had been ordered to retreat and the Libyan government said earlier that local tribes would take over the battle from the army. "Misrata is free, the rebels have won. Of Gaddafi's forces, some are killed and others are running away," anti-Gaddafi-forces spokesman [[Gemal Salem]] told Reuters by telephone from the city. He added that while pro-Gaddafi forces had retreated from the city, they were still outside and would be in a position to bombard it.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Anti-Gaddafi forces started to bring in supplies – through the border crossing at Wazzin – to the towns under siege in the [[Nafusa Mountains]]. However, it was confirmed that [[Yafran]] had been taken by pro-Gaddafi forces.<ref>Georgy, Michael (23 April 2011). [http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wwno/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1793328/World/Libya.troops.retreat.in.Misrata..rebels.claim.victory "Libya Troops Retreat in Misrata, Rebels Claim Victory"]. [[Reuters]] (via [[NPR]]). Retrieved 27 April 2011.</ref> During the pro-Gaddafi push into Yafran's center, seven anti-Gaddafi troops were killed and eleven were wounded.<ref>Staff (15 April 2011). [http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE73E22120110415 "Seven Rebels Killed in Western Libya – Rebel Spokesman"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 27 April 2011.</ref> *Rebels claimed that air-strikes on pro-Gaddafi's forces located on the Al Zaitoniya – Al Soihat road near Ajdabiya reportedly hit twenty-one army vehicles belonging to pro-Gaddafi's forces. However, there was no independent or NATO confirmation of the claim. On the same day, pro-Gaddafi forces also shelled al-Faluja, a small village near Ajdabiya.<ref>Staff (22 April 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-23 "Libya Live Blog – 23 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 27 April 2011.</ref>
===24 April=== *There was a heavy bombardment of Misrata, according to an opposition spokesman. "Gaddafi's brigades started random bombardment in the early hours of this morning. The bombardment is still going on. They targeted the city centre, mainly Tripoli Street, and three residential areas." NATO planes flew over, but there was no sign of air strikes.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Pro-Gaddafi forces were stationed in a residential area in Brega in large numbers with around eight [[BM-21 Grad|Grad]] batteries. When they tried to secretly surround Ajdabiya, NATO planes attacked them southwest of the city and in Mareer Qabes, an area northwest of the city.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *A NATO airstrike flattened a building inside Gaddafi's Bab al-Azizia compound early Monday, in what a press official from Gaddafi's government said was an attempt on the Libyan leader's life.<ref>Staff (24 April 2011). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/25/us-libya-airstrike-compound-idUSTRE73O08620110425?WT.tsrc=Social%20Media&WT.z_smid=twtr-reuters_%20com&WT.z_smid_dest=Twitter "NATO Jets Strike Inside Gaddafi Compound"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 27 April 2011.</ref>
===25 April=== *Witnesses said that rocket attacks on Misrata killed at least thirty and wounded sixty. "There is very intense and random shelling on residential areas. Burned bodies are being brought into the hospital," an employee of dissident radio station in Misrata said. "The number of wounded is 60 and the there were 30 martyrs. This is the toll for the past 12 hours," he added.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Four people were killed as pro-Gaddafi forces attacked Zintan with [[BM-21 Grad|Grad]] rockets, according to residents. Nine people were wounded in the attack which happened late on 24 April. Pro-Gaddafi forces fired between six and nine rockets, which crashed into homes.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *US officials said the attack on Tripoli, carried out by two Norwegian [[F-16 Fighting Falcon|F16]]s was intended to degrade 'command and control', the goal was not to assassinate Gaddafi. However, had he been at the site, he would have been a "legitimate target".{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *The BBC News reported that [[Prime Minister of Italy|Italian Prime Minister]] [[Silvio Berlusconi]] approved the use of Italian aircraft for ground attack missions in Libya as part of Operation Unified Protector.<ref>Staff (25 April 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13188951 "Libya: Berlusconi Backs Nato Strikes by Italy Jets"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 27 April 2011.</ref> *The [[Voice of Russia]] reported that rebels were growing active in the loyalist-held towns of [[Yafran]], [[Zliten]] and Abu Ruwayya, threatening loyalist communication lines into Misrata. Guerrilla attacks were also reported to be occurring in [[Zawiya, Libya|Zawiya]], which was occupied by pro-Gaddafi forces in mid-March following the prolonged and bloody [[First Battle of Zawiya]].<ref>Staff (25 April 2011). [http://english.ruvr.ru/2011/04/25/49411782.html "Gaddafi Troops Encircle Towns in West of Libya"]. [[Voice of Russia]].Retrieved 28 April 2011.</ref> *The African Union held a consultative meeting on Libya at the ministerial level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/consultative-meeting-libya-ministerial-level |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722092724/http://www.au.int/en/content/consultative-meeting-libya-ministerial-level |archivedate=22 July 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/communiqu%C3%A9-consultative-meeting-situation-libya-addis-ababa-ethiopia-25-march-2011 |title=Communiqué, Consultative Meeting on the Situation in Libya Addis Ababa, Ethiopia 25 March 2011. | African Union |publisher=Au.int |date= |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/african-union-ad-hoc-high%E2%80%90level-committee-libya-convenes-its-second-meeting-addis-ababa-comm |title=The African Union Ad Hoc High‐Level Committee on Libya Convenes its Second Meeting in Addis Ababa; the Committee Interacted With a Delegation of the Libyan Government. | African Union |publisher=Au.int |date=2011-03-26 |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref>
===26 April=== *The Peace and Security Council of the African Union (AU), at its 275th Meeting, situation in Libya.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/peace-and-security-council-african-union-au-its-275th-meeting-held-26-april-2011-held-minist |title=The Peace and Security Council of the African Union (AU), at its 275th Meeting Held on 26 April 2011, Held at Ministerial Level, Adopted the Following Decision on the Situation in Libya. | African Union |publisher=Au.int |date= |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref> *The African Union High Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya Convenes its Fourth Meeting in Addis Ababa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/african-union-high%E2%80%90level-ad-hoc-committee-libya-convenes-its-fourth-meeting-addis-ababa |title=The African Union High‐Level Ad Hoc Committee on Libya Convenes its Fourth Meeting in Addis Ababa. | African Union |publisher=Au.int |date=2011-04-27 |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref> *Report of the Chairperson of the Commission on the Activities of the AU High Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on the Situation in Libya.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/report-chairperson-commission-activities-au-high-level-ad-hoc-committee-situation-libya |title=Report of the Chairperson of the Commission on the Activities of the AU High Level AD HOC Committee on the Situation in Libya. | African Union |publisher=Au.int |date=2011-04-27 |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref> *Pro-Gaddafi forces reinforced their position around Brega. They dug in their long-range missile batteries to conceal them from NATO warplanes, according to an opposition commander.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *A ship chartered by the [[World Food Programme]] delivered more than 500 metric tonnes of food assistance, three ambulances, medical supplies and other relief items on behalf of humanitarian partners to Misrata. It also offloaded 150 metric tonnes of mixed food including pasta, rice, potatoes; 84 metric tonnes of bottled water; 12 metric tonnes of medicines and three ambulances on behalf of [[UNICEF]], and other international aid organisations. This was the second delivery of the programme.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *It was reported that Russia had said it would not support any UN Security Council resolutions on Libya which could escalate the conflict in Libya. "If a resolution leads to a further escalation of a civil war by any means, including outside intervention, we will not be able to support this", [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Russian Foreign Minister]] [[Sergei Lavrov]] was quoted as saying by [[Interfax]]. Russian Prime Minister Putin had said that the coalition had no mandate to kill Gaddafi.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Gaddafi's government was circumventing sanctions by importing gasoline from Italian refiner [[Saras S.p.A.|Saras]], taking advantage of a loophole in the UN sanctions that permits purchases by companies not on a UN list of banned entities. In early April, a cargo ship sailed from Italy to [[La Shikhra]], Tunisia, where it transferred its load onto a Libyan ship.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} *US President Obama authorized US$25 million in non-lethal aid to anti-Gaddafi forces.<ref>Staff (26 April 2011). [http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/04/26/obama-authorizes-25-million-non-lethal-aid-libyan-rebels/ "Obama Authorizes $25 Million in Non-Lethal Aid to Libyan Rebels"]. [[Fox News]]. Retrieved 29 April 2011.</ref>
===27 April=== *Devastation mounts in Misrata after heavy shelling on port.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/27/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T1 "Witness: NATO Airstrike Kills 11 Rebels in Misrata"]. [[CNN]]. Retrieved 1 May 2011.</ref> *Gaddafi forces have started firing mortar rounds at a district in the west of the city of Misrata, an opposition spokesman said on Wednesday. "They (pro-Gaddafi forces) attacked the Abu Rouia area, in the west of Misrata. They carried out intense bombardment, using mortars", the spokesman, called Safieddin, told Reuters from the city.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *NATO airstrikes killed eleven rebels and wounded two in Misrata.<ref>[http://articles.cnn.com/2011-04-27/world/libya.war_1_nato-airstrike-civilians-nato-plane?_s=PM:WORLD "Witness: NATO Airstrike Kills 11 Rebels in Misrata"]. [[CNN]]. 27 April 2011. Retrieved 11 June 2011.</ref>
===28 April=== *The evacuation ship ''Red Star'' finally managed to leave the port of Misrata for Benghazi. It had first been prevented from docking and then from leaving as Gaddafi forces continuously shelled the port. The ship was carrying nearly 1,000 migrant workers and 25 seriously injured.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Loyalist forces re-captured [[Kufra]], the main city in Libya's [[Kufra District]] region. There were no reports of casualties in the fighting for the town after the rebels put up only light resistance.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13223197 "Libya: Nato Strike 'Kills Rebels' in Misrata"]. [[BBC News]] (21 April 2011). Retrieved 1 May 2011.</ref> *Gaddafi forces re-captured the Wazzin border crossing with Tunisia after a swift advance in which they pushed the rebels back over the border into Tunisia where the fighting continued on the edge of the Tunisian border town of Dehiba.<ref>[http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-28 "Libya Live Blog – 28 April"]. [[Al Jazeera]] (27 April 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/28/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110428 "Libyan Forces Overrun Rebels on Tunisian Border"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref><ref>Staff (29 April 2011). [http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2011/04/29/97001-20110429FILWWW00462-libyetunisie-combats-a-la-frontiere.php "''Libye/Tunisie : combats à la frontière"''] (in French). [[Reuters]] (via ''[[Le Figaro]]'') Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref>
===29 April=== *Libyan opposition fighters manned a checkpoint on the road leading out of Ajdabiya westwards toward government-held Brega on Thursday, signaling a possible stalemate in the ongoing conflict for lack of progress by either side. Opposition fighters erected barricades near the western entrance of Ajdabiya, the last major town before Benghazi and the key oil exporting terminal of Tobruk.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Rebels claimed for a third time in a row to have re-taken the Wazzin border post after a night of heavy fighting.<ref>[http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE73S00320110429?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 "Pro-Gaddafi Forces Clash with Tunisian Military"]. [[Reuters]] (29 April 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref> However, Al Jazeera confirmed that the Gaddafi green flag of Libya was still flying over the border post thus proving that government troops were still in control.<ref>{{cite news |work=Al Jazeera|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-29|title=Libya Live Blog|date= 29 April 2011}}</ref> *Air strikes hit Gaddafi forces surrounding Zintan.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Gaddafi forces have bombarded the opposition at the Wazin border crossing. A Tunisian told Reuters that very heavy bombardment was going on and they were trying to retake the crossing.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} *Libyan state television threatened that any ship that tried to enter Misrata's port would be attacked, regardless of the justification. It also said that government attacks had rendered the port "non-functional".{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}
===30 April=== *Fighting was shifting to the edges of Misrata, turning small village clinics into trauma centres, witnesses told Al Jazeera.<ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite news |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-april-30|title=Libya Live Blog|date=30 April 2011|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=1 May 2011}}</ref> *Libyan state television says NATO had bombed close to the television building during Gaddafi's speech early on Saturday morning.<ref name="aljazeera2"/> *Libyan state media and government officials claimed that Gaddafi's second youngest son, [[Saif al-Arab Gaddafi]], was killed by a NATO air strike on the night of 30 April. Three of Gaddafi's grandchildren were allegedly killed in the same strike.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/338B2C39-54B0-429D-BF7C-277E4820B167.html "'' الأخبار – عربي – مقتل نجل للقذافي بغارة للناتو''"]. (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]).[[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 1 May 2011.</ref> *Eyewitnesses in the embattled Libyan city of Misrata reported especially intense shelling by pro-Gaddafi forces overnight. "There's been continuous and heavy shelling for three hours straight," said one man, talking to CNN from about five kilometers from Misrata's city center. "There have been a lot of explosions."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/04/30/libya.war/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Witnesses: Attacks Intensify in Misrata, Benghazi After Fatal Strike|publisher= CNN|accessdate=1 May 2011}}</ref>
==May==
===1 May=== *Shells fired at the Libyan–Tunisian border near [[Wazzin]] land in Tunisia; no casualties were reported.<ref>[http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE74009920110501 "Libyan Artillery Rounds Land in Tunisian Town"]. [[Reuters]] (1 May 2011). Retrieved 7 May 2011.</ref> *Moscow strongly condemned NATO for bombing Gaddafi's complex, stating that its mandate was to "protect, not kill Libyans".<ref>[http://english.ruvr.ru/2011/05/01/49714725.html "NATO After Assassinating Gaddafi – Moscow"]. [[Voice of Russia]] (1 May 2011). Retrieved 7 May 2011.</ref> *NATO stated that the Libyan government had no evidence of Saif's death, and furthermore claimed that what the Libyan government had called a "residence" actually held an underground bunker which was used as a command and control center and that was the target.<ref>[http://news.brisbanetimes.com.au/breaking-news-world/no-evidence-gaddafis-son-killed-nato-20110502-1e3ko.html "No Evidence Gaddafi's Son Killed: NATO"]. ''[[Brisbane Times]]'' (2 May 2011). Retrieved 7 May 2011.</ref> *The ''[[Times of Malta]]'' reported its contacts in Misrata said soldiers loyal to Gaddafi had been issued [[gas mask]]s and were wearing them in and around the city. The report came amidst fears Gaddafi could use [[chemical weapon]]s to retaliate for his son's reported death.<ref>[http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110501/world/gas-masks.363135 "Pro-Regime Troops Seen 'Wearing Gas Masks in Misurata'"]. ''[[The Times (Malta)|The Times]]'' (1 May 2011). Retrieved 7 May 2011.</ref> *The British and Italian embassies came under attack, and this along with general unrest prompted the removal of the British ambassador and UN international staff. An estimated £130,000 worth of art at the UK mission was destroyed.<ref>[http://news.scotsman.com/politics/130000-art-feared-lost-after.6785209.jp "£130,000 Art Feared Lost After Mob Attack on the UK Embassy in Tripoli"]. ''[[The Scotsman]]''. 15 June 2011. Retrieved 14 June 2011.</ref> Meanwhile, Gaddafi claimed the building hit in the Saturday strike was not a command center.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/01/us-libya-embassies-idUSTRE7401YM20110501 "UK, Italy Say Their Embassies in Italy Attacked"]. [[Reuters]] (1 May 2011). Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/01/us-libya-un-staff-idUSTRE7401VG20110501 "U.N. Says International Staff Leaves Tripoli"]. [[Reuters]] (1 May 2011). Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/01/us-libya-govt-idUSTRE74032P20110501 "Libya Denies Command Center Was Hit in Saturday Strike"]. [[Reuters]] (1 May 2011). Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref>
===2 May=== *Fighting took place in Western Libya, around Zintan.
===3 May=== *Rebels were low on money and hope for funding from Western powers.<ref>[http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/libyas_rebel_government_asks_for_3_billion_in_international_loans/2011/05/03/AFdADVjF_story.html?wprss=rss_world "Libya's Rebel Government Asks for $3 Billion in International Loans"]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref>
===4 May=== *Agence France-Presse reported that loyalists attacked Misrata's port.
===5 May=== *US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton announced that the Obama administration hoped to free a small portion of the more than $30 billion it had frozen in Libyan assets to support Gaddafi opponents, pending approval from Congress.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/05/05/136011330/rome-hosts-diplomatic-talks-on-libya|publisher = Associated Press (via [[NPR]]) |title=U.S. To Use Frozen Libya Assets To Fund Rebels|date=5 May 2011|accessdate=5 May 2011}}</ref> *Spain, Denmark and the Netherlands denied rebel claims that their governments recognize the National Transitional Council in lieu of the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/05/us-libya-meeting-recognition-idUSTRE7442HE20110505 "Three Countries Deny Libya Rebel Recognition Claim"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref> *Turkey released a plan hoping for a ceasefire between the warring Libyans. The plan failed to materialize.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822171305/http://mullahomar.org/?xstart=mmhcm&new=77496 |url=http://mullahomar.org/?xstart=mmhcm&new=77496 |archivedate=2011-08-22 |title=Libyan rebels pass on Turkey's revised road map |date=May 6, 2011 }}</ref> *Chairperson of the African Union Commission Dr. Jean Ping presented remarks during a meeting of the International Contact Group on Libya, held in Rome, Italy.<ref>Transcript (5 May 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/statement-chairperson-african-union-commission-dr-jean-ping-meeting-international-contact-gr "Statement of the Chairperson of the African Union Commission, Dr. Jean Ping, at the Meeting of the International Contact Group on Libya – Rome, Italy, 5 May 2011"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 15 August 2011.</ref>
===6 May=== *[[Amnesty International]] accused Gaddafi's government of committing war crimes in Misrata by "deliberately targeting and killing civilians".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Amnesty+International+accuses+Gadhafi+regime+crimes+Misurata/4741746/story.html| work = [[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]] |title=Amnesty International Accuses Gadhafi Regime of War Crimes in Misurata|date=6 May 2011|accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref>
===7 May=== *Loyalist forces hit the main fuel depot in Misrata on Saturday. *Forces loyal to Gaddafi attacked the remote eastern oil town of Jalu in the Libyan desert on Saturday, but the town remained in rebel hands, a rebel spokesman said.<ref name="aljazeera2"/> *Forces loyal to Gaddafi bombed large fuel storage tanks in Misrata, destroying the tanks and causing a large fire.<ref>[http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE74605L20110507 "Update 2-Libyan Forces Destroy Misrata Fuel Tanks-Rebels"]. [[Reuters]] (7 May 2011). Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref> *The BBC News reported that loyalist forces had put a number of mines in Misrata.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13323299 "Libya 'Scatters Mines' in Misrata"]. [[BBC News]] (7 May 2011). Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref>
===8 May=== *The national forum of leaders and dignitaries of the Libyan tribes called for a debate to promulgate a new constitution and described as void all agreements and commitments proposed by the NTC with any foreign country.<ref>[http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/libyan-chiefs,-dignitaries-call-for-new-constitution-2011050811147.html "Libyan Chiefs, Dignitaries Call for New Constitution"]. Afrique en Ligne. 8 May 2011.</ref>
===11 May=== *Libyan rebel forces captured Misrata airport after hours of overnight fighting, burning government tanks as loyalist forces retreated.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13363782 "Libya Rebels 'Capture Misrata Airport'"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref> *The first shipment of non-lethal US aid to the Libyan opposition arrived in Benghazi.<ref>[http://www.sacbee.com/2011/05/10/3616254/first-us-aid-shipment-for-libyan.html "First US Aid Shipment for Libyan Rebels Arrives"]. ''[[The Sacramento Bee]]'' (10 May 2011). Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref> *While human rights organizations warned of indiscriminate attacks in the Nafusa mountains, refugees spoke of kidnappings in the village of Ghezaya which was surrounded by Gaddafi's troops.<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/05/10/libya-west-village-idUKLDE74924020110510 "Accounts of Abduction on Libya's Western Front"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref> *[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Polish Foreign Affairs Ministers]] [[Radoslaw Sikorski]], as a first member of the [[Libya Contact Group]], was in Benghazi. During the visit, the Polish government provided medical aid to injured civilians. Sikorski met with representatives of the Interim Transitional National Council, including its chief Mustafa Abdul Jalil.<ref>[http://www.msz.gov.pl/Foreign,Minister,Radoslaw,Sikorski,visits,Benghazi,43100.html "Foreign Minister Radosław Sikorski Visits Benghazi"]. [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]. Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref>
===13 May=== *Libyan rebels' foreign minister was set to request financial assistance during talks with US officials in Washington, D.C.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/video/africa/2011/05/20115139534241170.html "Libyan Rebels Seek US Recognition"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref> *Pressure was mounting on Gaddafi from within his stronghold in Tripoli, with increasing NATO airstrikes and worsening shortages of fuel and goods. An activist said on Friday that there had also been a wave of anti-government protests in several Tripoli neighborhoods that week.<ref>Staff (14 May 2011).[http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-0#may12 "Libya Live Blog"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref> *Gaddafi stated in an audio clip to NATO saying "you cannot kill me".<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/13/gaddafi-to-nato-you-canno_n_861814.html "Gaddafi to NATO: 'You Cannot Kill Me'"]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref> *A NATO airstrike at dawn killed at least 16 civilians, according to Libya state television, including a group of Muslim religious leaders who were holding a religious ceremony. NATO at first denied any knowledge of the incident, later admitting to striking a building labelled as a command and control bunker.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/13/us-libya-brega-attack-idUSTRE74C2UY20110513 "NATO Strike Kills at Least 16 in Brega: Report"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/14/us-libya-nato-brega-idUSTRE74D07U20110514 "NATO Says Brega Strike Directed at Command Bunker"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref>
===15 May=== *Pro Gaddafi forces withdrew from the Misrata which had been under siege for almost three months. Opposition forces declared the battle for the city to be over and advanced to the Dafniya area to the west and the Tawergha area to the east, establishing a defensive perimeter around Misrata .<ref>Staff (15 May 2011). [http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/05/15/misrata-rebels.html?ref=rss "Libyan Rebels Claim Misrata"]. [[Associated Press]] (via [[CBC News]]). Retrieved 15 August 2011.</ref>
===16 May=== *Thousands of telecommunications workers vowed to act as human shields against NATO airstrikes targeting communications buildings, which had suffered $1.25 billion in damages.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/16/us-libya-telecoms-idUSTRE74F6S920110516 "Libya Says Telecom Staff To Act Shield Against NATO"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref>
===17 May=== *Xinhua News Agency reported that the Chief Prosecutor of the [[International Criminal Court]] had issued a request for an arrest warrant against Gaddafi for "crimes against humanity".<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/video/2011-05/17/c_13878741.htm "ICC Requests Gaddafi Arrest Warrant]. [[Xinhua News Agency]] (17 May 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref> *Tunisia warned Libya for the second time to prevent its troops from firing towards Tunisia, threatening a diplomatic response from the U.N. Security Council.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/17/us-libya-tunisia-border-idUSTRE74G6GF20110517 "Tunisia Warns Libya Over Border Shelling"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 20 May 2011.</ref>
===18 May=== *The [[government of Canada|Canadian government]] announced the acquisition of 1300 "smart bombs".<ref>Pugliese, David (18 May 2011). [http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Canada+buys+more+smart+munitions/4941043/story.html "Canada Orders 1,300 Smart Bombs"]. ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]''. Retrieved 14 June 2011.</ref>
===19 May=== *''[[The Economist]]'' reported that [[Jalal al-Digheily]], a civilian, had replaced [[Omar El-Hariri]] as the NTC's defense minister. The precise date of Digheily's appointment was unclear.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18713650?story_id=18713650&fsrc=rss|work=The Economist|date=19 May 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011|title=Libya: The Colonel Feels the Squeeze}}</ref>
===20 May=== *NATO airstrikes targeted several ships in Tripoli's port, a loyalist asset which had become an increasing threat to the waters off Misrata. Meanwhile, opposition forces battled with Gaddafi forces for control of two major highways in the Nafusa Mountains range.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43106115/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|title=NATO Bombs Gadhafi Warships|publisher= [[MSNBC]]|date=20 May 2011|accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
===21 May=== *NATO launched airstrikes near Gaddafi's complex in Tripoli while a bus carrying foreign journalists was attacked by civilians armed with guns and knives while waiting to refuel at a Tripoli petrol station.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/22/us-libya-nato-idUSTRE74J52M20110522|title=Factbox: Latest Military Activity in Libya for 22 May 2011|agency=Reuters |author =Brunnstrom, David|date=22 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===22 May=== *Though loyalist forces continued to launch attacks and shell the city from its outskirts, opposition forces claimed liberation of Misrata, [[Battle of Misrata|besieged since February]] by Gaddafi's troops.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/22/us-libya-misrata-idUSTRE74L0YR20110522|title=Libya's Misrata Struggles To Recover After Weeks of Siege| author =Abbas, Mohammed|agency=Reuters |date=22 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===23 May=== *France and the UK announced plans to use [[attack helicopters]] in order to increase NATO's accuracy and ability to strike [[urban warfare|urban targets]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/23/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110523| title = France and Britain To Use Attack Helicopters in Libya |agency=Reuters |author1=Irish, John |author2=Abbad, Mohammed |date=23 May 2011|accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref> *[[The Canadian Press]] reported that Democrats and Republicans in the [[United States Senate|US Senate]] had agreed on a resolution allowing US military intervention in Libya. *Turkey recognized the NTC as the sole legitimate representative of the Libyan people.<ref>Staff (23 May 2011). [http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1640934.php/Turkey-recognizes-Libyan-rebels "Turkey Recognizes Libyan Rebels"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110527000000/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1640934.php/Turkey-recognizes-Libyan-rebels |date=27 May 2011 }}. [[Deutsche Press-Agentur]] (via [[Monsters and Critics]]). Retrieved 16 August 2011.</ref>
===24 May=== *More than twenty NATO airstrikes hit Tripoli near Gaddhafi's compound in the largest offensive attack on the capital since foreign intervention began. At least three people were reported killed and dozens wounded according to government spokesman [[Moussa Ibrahim]].<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43140642/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ "US Reaches Out to Libya Rebels Amid Airstrikes"]. [[MSNBC]] (24 May 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref>
===25 May=== *It was announced that [[President of South Africa|South African President]] [[Jacob Zuma]] planned to visit Gaddafi in Tripoli next week to discuss a find a "lasting solution" to the current crisis there. He clarified earlier statements and insisted that the visit was not necessarily to find an "exit strategy" for Gaddafi, sowing doubt as to whether Gaddafi would concede to surrendering power, a demand the NTC had insisted was not negotiable.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/25/us-libya-safrica-idUSTRE74O1NU20110525|title=South Africa's Zuma To Meet Gaddafi for Talks|agency=Reuters| author =Bosch, Marius|date=25 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *[[Khaled Kaim]], Libya's deputy foreign minister allegedly claimed that the Gaddafi administration saw all options open in future negotiations and that Gaddafi might step down if terms were agreed upon by both sides.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8537123/Libya-regime-negotiates-Col-Muammar-Gaddafis-position-for-first-time.html|title=Libya: Regime Negotiates Col. Muammar Gaddafi's Position for First Time|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK| author = Spencer, Richard|date=26 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===26 May=== *Gaddafi's prime minister sent letters to foreign governments looking to negotiate a ceasefire in Libya.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/exclusive-battered-libya-sues-for-peace-2289133.html "Exclusive: Battered Libya Sues for Peace"]. ''[[The Independent]]'' (26 May 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref> *French President Nicolas Sarkozy urged Gaddafi to step down as "all options are open."<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13564999?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter "G8 Summit: Sarkozy Offers Libya's Gaddafi 'Options'"]. [[BBC News]] (26 May 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref> *Libya's EU ambassador Hadeiba Hadi defected from the Gaddafi government along with his staff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/libya-conflict.a7i |title=Libya's EU ambassador defects along with staff — EU – European Union and Eurozone business news |publisher=EUbusiness.com |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2015-02-18}}</ref> *The African Union High-Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya convened its fifth meeting in [[Addis Ababa]], Ethiopia.<ref>Press release (27 May 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/african-union-high-level-ad-hoc-committee-libya-convened-its-5th-meeting-addis-ababa "The African Union High-Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya Convened Its 5th Meeting in Addis Ababa"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref> *The chairperson of the African Union Commission met with the UN secretary-general while at the African Union Extraordinary Summit.<ref>Press release (27 May 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/chairperson-african-union-commission-meets-un-secretary-general-margins-au-extraordinary-sum "The Chairperson of the African Union Commission Meets with UN Secretary General, on the Margins of the AU Extraordinary Summit"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref> *There was a meeting of the High Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya, at the Level of Heads of States.<ref>Press release (24 May 2011). [http://www.au.int/en/content/meeting-high-level-ad-hoc-committee-libya-level-heads-states "Meeting of the High Level ''Ad Hoc'' Committee on Libya, at the Level of Heads of States"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[African Union]]. Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref> *The United Kingdom announced plans to send four Apache helicopters to aid in the conflict.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13585019|title=Libya: NATO Planes Target Gaddafi's Tripoli Compound|publisher=BBC News|date=28 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===27 May=== *NATO allies rejected the most recent Libyan cease-fire offer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304520804576348763459684864.html|title=G-8 Calls for Gadhafi's Exit|date=27 May 2011|author1=Parkinson, Joe |author2=Gauthiers-Villars, David |author3=Spencer, Mimosa |work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> *Russia joined many Western countries' demands for Gaddafi to leave power.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/05/27/uk-libya-idUKTRE74E1I420110527|title=Russia Joins Western Chorus for Gaddafi To Go|author= Logan, Joseph |date=27 May 2011|agency=Reuters}}</ref> *NATO jets fired on and destroyed the guard towers surrounding Gaddafi's Tripolitanian military complex, Bab al-Azizia.<ref name="BBC News"/> *A total of 151 sorties were conducted which included 45 strike sorties. Key hits were: in Tripoli: 1 Command & Control Facility. In the vicinity of Sirte: 1 Ammunition Storage Facility. In the vicinity of Mizda: 1 Ammunition Storage Facility. In the vicinity of Misrata: 1 Rocket Launcher, 2 Truck-Mounted Guns. In the vicinity of Hun: 1 Ammunition Storage Facility. In the vicinity of Zintan: 4 Surface-To-Air Missile Launchers.<ref name="nato.int">Press release (28 May 2011). [http://www.nato.int/nato_static/assets/pdf/pdf_2011_05/20110528_110528-oup-update.pdf "Operational Media Update for 27 May"] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF format]]). [[NATO]]. Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref> *As of 27 May, a total of twenty NATO ships were actively patrolling the Central Mediterranean.<ref name="nato.int"/>
===29 May=== *More than 100 tribal and community leaders from Libya met with NTC members at a conference in [[Istanbul]], Turkey on 28 and 29 May. The delegates called for an end to violence in Libya and the departure of Libyan leader Gaddafi and his sons. Most of the tribal leaders gathered were from the large [[Warfalla]] clan, based in the region around [[Bani Walid]].<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/05/2011529153314220843.html "Libyan Tribal Leaders Call for United Front"]. [[Al Jazeera English]] (29 May 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref>
===30 May=== *As many as 120 of Gaddafi's military officials and soldiers were reported to have defected by Libyan UN Ambassador Abdurrahman Shalgam, a former Gaddafi official who joined the opposition. Among the high-ranking officials who defected (which included five generals, two colonels, and a major), General Oun Ali Oun was quoted as saying during a Roman press conference, "There is a lot of killing, genocide...violence against women. No wise, rational person with the minimum of dignity can do what we saw with our eyes and what he asked us to do."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43217134/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|title=S. African President: Gadhafi Ready for Truce|publisher= [[MSNBC]]|date=31 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/30/us-libya-idUSTRE7270JP20110530|title=Officers Disown Gaddafi as Peace Bid Stall|agency=Reuters|author = Graff, Peter|date=30 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> *Al Jazeera reported that "unprecedented protests" occurred in Tripoli. Large demonstrations such as these had previously been limited by the heavy security presence, indicating the growing boldness of the populace of Tripoli. The protesters were eventually dispersed by live fire from security forces.<ref>[http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-may-30-2011-2350 "''Libya Live Blog'': Monday, 30 May 2011 – 23:50"]. [[Al Jazeera]] (30 May 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref>
===31 May=== *Fighting broke out in the pro-Gaddafi stronghold of [[Bani Walid]] ''(see also [[Timeline of the Libyan civil war#29 May|29 May]])'' between rebels and Gaddafi soldiers, in which thirteen rebels and three loyalists were killed. Nine of the rebels were killed as prisoners of war, and government forces refused to give the bodies of the dead rebels back to their families.<ref>[http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-may-31-2011-1503 "''Libya Live Blog'': Tuesday, 31 May 2011 – 14:03"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. (31 May 2011). Retrieved 13 June 2011.</ref> *It was reported that the UN Humanitarian Coordinator for Libya said that the food supplies in parts of Libya that Gaddafi controlled might run out within weeks causing crisis among the general populace.<ref>Graff, Peter (31 May 2011). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/31/us-libya-un-food-idUSTRE74U23W20110531 "Food Running Out in Gaddafi-Held Libya: U.N."]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref> *The Libyan government claimed NATO air raids had killed 718 civilians and injured more than 4,000 since the bombing campaign to enforce a no-fly zone began.<ref>Staff (31 May 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13611132 "Libya Says Nato Air Raids 'Killed 700 Civilians'"]. [[BBC News]] (31 May 2011). Retrieved 18 August 2011.</ref>
